text: Ar: Deep toasty malt; steely clean yeast profile; slight caramel. Ap: Deep amber-orange; small off-white head with moderate-low retention, leaving a ring of motley bubbles and a very fine cap of mostly-covering haze. T: Toffee and caramel up front, transitions into deep toasted malt; medium-low sweetness; clean alcohol warmth; slight black tea astringency, with a medium-low bitterness; finish is clean booze, medium caramels, and sticky toast. P: Medium-full body; medium-high carbonation; creamy; finish is medium-dry. O: Interesting interpretation of the doppelbock style that is drinkable but misses the mark; rich maltiness is pronounced, though some of the caramel and alcohol flavors are too prominent, unbalancing the beer somewhat, distracting from the deep base-malt toastiness and smoothness of a great doppelbock.

2006 vintage, 22oz bottle, dark brown color, with a beige head, mild oxidized, maderized fruity nose of dark dried fruits, with some fruitcake, faint watery port wine, even kind of corky, fruity toasted, caramelized, biscuity, breads, roasted malty accents, and a subtle raisin pie crust, toffee, subtle prune juice, faint bran muffin, granola bar note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a warmth fruity caramelized, biscuity, toasted, bread, roasted malty, fruitcake character, with some oxidized, maderized, toffee, sugar pie crust, subtle earthy flowery leafy, citrus hop, subtle caramel lollipop, subtle semi bitter chocolate baking bar flavours, leading towards a warming oxidized fruity toasted, biscuity, caramelized, bready, roasted maltiness finish.

2014 vintage.
Poured into a lager glass, the appearance was a ruddy burnt amber almost brown color with an ever so sly transparency about it. Carbonation could be seen rising at a moderate pace to fill a one and a half fingered white foamy head that dissipated at a nice pace. Moderate sticky lace running here and there.
The aroma takes on sweet bready malts nuanced by sweet rich dark fruits. Sly allspice. Dark chocolate. Milk chocolate. Roasted nuts.
The flavor blends all of those aromas together superbly. Malty smooth semi-sticky aftertaste flowing into the finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a pretty good sessionabiltiy about it. Carbonation seems to have been fairly dissipated, but I expected that.
Overall, damn nice aged dopplebock that I would love to have again and am hoping to find a fresh one. 2014 bottle really aged awesome!

Bottle @ Oliver Twist, Stockholm. Clear deep amber red with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit and light oxydized. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. Oily and soft. 270716
Dark amber color, hazy. Caramel malt, spices, and hop aromas. Caramel taste, alcohol and spices. Slight hop taste during finish. A bit boozy.
Pours a nice deep golden brown color. Aromas of rich dark malts, chocolate, fruit. Flavor is rich with a lot of flavors light chocolate, dark fruit, smoke, coffee.

Bottle @ home. Cellared 14 months. Copper to red color with a small tan head and a little lacing. Warming malty and fruity aroma with raisins apricots, toffee, dark bread, plums, biscuits and nuts. Big bodied with low to medium carbonation. Lots of fruits and sweet maltiness in the taste. Flavors of toffee caramel, plums, apricots, raisins, bread, nuts and syrup. Finish is spicy and fruity with some chocolate and well hidden alcohols. Distinctly bitter and quite dry, overall balanced finish. Really nice.

Big and malty are the two words for this. The malt flavor dominates throughout, and its really complex and tasty. Lots of caramel and fruit flavor, with a bit of grainy toastiness too. Great example of the style.

Bottle:
Slightly hazy, brown, with a beige head.
Baked dark bread, toffee, raisin scent.
Taste is sweet, old raisins.....toffee malt, a little alcohol bittering.
Pretty nice.....wish it were a tad chewier, though.

Chesnut colored pour with small light tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, dried fruits and bread dough. Taste of caramel malts, dried fruits, bread dough, spices and roasted nuts. Full bodied, lower carbonation, nicely balanced.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Small dense light beige head. Aroma. Caramel, ripe fruits, sweetness, light spice. Flavour. Caramel, light bread, ripe fruits, spice, alcohol, sweetness. Medium bodied. Ends fruity and sweet.
Some roast and light coffee dose. Pours brown with some head. Lots of nice malt. Caramel. Light sweet finish. Thick consistency. Easy drinking. Tap at Churchkey.

Bottle. Raisin, toffee malt, hay, and alcohol aroma. Medium brown with small head. Sweet raisin/dried apricot, toffee malt, and moderately bitter herbal hay and alcohol flavor. Body on the light side for the style. Pretty good.
Bomber. Pours a muddy brown with a tan head and aroma of malt and caramel. Taste is of malt and caramel up front, with alcohol and bread notes into the malty finish.

With Z, pours a rich black pour with a sustained beige head. Nose is deep caramel and toffee, sweet and sugary. Taste is sweet chocolate malt with the alcohol punching through, quite tasty since I do not relish doppels. Finishes on the same sweet chocolate tasting notes with a moderately long finish. Good Doppelbock. quaff score 7 / 10

650ml bottle from Systembolaget. Clear amber, creamy beige head, rich lacing. Sweet caramelized aroma, roasted dark sugar, caramel, sticky dried dark fruit. Smooth and low carbonated. The taste is sweet, dark honey, dark bread, caramel and butterscotch. Faint hint of alcohol in the finish.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Tempo. Thanks Excellent Little Brother for the delivery! Hazy brown with a beige head. Old grapes and dark fruit aroma, sweet, dark fruit taste. Full body, very fizzy and boozy finish.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Tempo. Thanks kerenmk. Clear amber. Aroma of malt, caramel, honey, some stale hops, and some fruitiness. Sweet flavor, malty, caramelly, with honey, molasses, stale hops, some fruitiness, and a mildly bitterish finish with some alcohol. Medium-bodied, kinda oily.

Bottle: It poured a murky chestnut color with very small white head. The aroma has dried fruit, caramel and toffee malt notes. The favor is the same with a slight alcohol finish. Overall it is well balanced but does have a bit of dryness at the end.
In bottiglia 65cl. Aroma di legno, malto, frutta secca, nocciola. Al palato corpo robusto, bassa gasatura, sentori di legno, frutta secca, nocciola, leggero cioccolato, alcool ben avvertibile.
Provad parallellt med Paulaner Salvator. Brun öl med med beige skum. Söt maltighet och torkad frukt i doft och smak. Även karamell och lätt kryddighet.

It pours dark amber with a light brown head. It produces lacing as the head goes away It has a toffee, roasted, slightly chocolate aroma It has a sweet taste with malts that include nuts, toffee, and chocolate flavors. It has a pleasant sweet taste on the palate.

Pours a deep cherry-wood into the glass, with amber-fringed hues. A reductive wispy head ensues, with trace lacing left over. The nose is of caramel and fruit/nut bread. Deep caramel and toffee, plums, sweet dark-pitted fruits, dates, and some light chalky pepper to finish. The ABV is noted, but well-integrated and never takes over. Substantial, yet smooth to the palate, this brew really opens up as it warms, where notes of oak and whiskey add to the complexity. A nice sipper for an aperitif or nightcap, definitely! Very nicely put together and enjoyable, reminiscent of a good cognac. Will have again!

bomber - nose is toffee/caramel (sweet). Sip adds booze, grass, roast, and more grass. Nose as sweet as the style suggest nor the nose. A little flat, but the roasted malt presence was a nice surprise.

An ok doppelbock, a bit one-note. Pours a muddy red with a tan head. Smells of maple syrup, honey, and strawberries. Taste is very sweet, with honey, strawberries and pepper. Malty aftertaste. Had in the bottle.
Rødbrun farve med lyst skum. Lukt av malt, karamell, honning, frukt og nøtter. Smak av malt, karamell, honning, frukt og nøtter. Lokal øl-smaking på Bryne; 3xUntappd, 2xRateBeer & 1xNeutral.

Lukt: Rosin og karamell.
Utseende: Mørk gulbrun farge.
Skum/kullsyre: Lite skum.
Smak: Rosin, vørter, karamell og krydder.

Bottle. Pours clear reddish brown with very little head. Nose and taste is caramel toffee and a little chocolate. A little bitterness in the aftertaste. Good.

How: Bottle.
Where: Systembolaget.
Appearance: Amber colour with an off-white head.
Aroma: Malt, caramel, dried fruit.
Body: Medium to full body, low carbonation.
Flavour: Malt, caramel, bread, raising, dried fruit, some alcohol.

Bottle 65 cl from Systembolaget. Clear light mahogany with a white head. Caramel, red berries, red apples, some fruity sweetness, slight red wine/tartness. Lots of fudge, nice bitterness, some sweetness. Medium/full body, generous carbonation, bitter finish with fruity notes. Very interesting and nice flavours and aromas, but a bit too heavy body for me personally.
Mahogany brown color, beige head. Caramel nose, fruity, light roasted malt, alcohol note. Sweet taste, prunes, caramel, malty, bread, hint of wood. Medium to full body, soft carbonation.

650 ml bottle from systembolaget. Dark copper with white head. Smell is sweet honey and syrup. Taste is sweet honey, syrup and dried fruit balanced with gentle hay and earthy bitterness and a warming alcohol finishing. Semi sweet with low bitterness and medium carbonation.

February 25, 2015. Bottle at home, best before october 9, 2015. 
Ruby red with a small dense off-white head. Aroma is malty with hard bread, caramel, nuts, dark fruits and herbs. Taste is sweet malty with toffee, hard bread and caramel with a light roasted bitterness up front. Finish is sweet with an roasted, earthy, herbal and quite dry bitterness. Medium bodied, oily texture, small bubble carbonation.

Bottle from Systembolaget. 

Clear dark amber with a medium head. Sweet with malt, caramel, syryp and some light notes of dried fruit. Warming alcohol in the finish. Not bad but I prefer a Doppelbock with more malt.

Pours dark brown with an amber tint and an off white head. Aroma is toasted malt, grain, and fruity sweetness. Flavor is sweet toasted malt and grain with dark dried fruits and some bready yeastiness. Finish has some alcohol warmth and some hopiness. Really nice dopplebock

(bottle)  Aroma of candy, floral and malt.  Mahogany complexion with thick tan head and glass lacing. The flavor is complex and rich.   Malty with sweetness without cloying. ABV well concealed.  Very well crafted for the style.

Bottle. Dark amber, reddish, clear. Malty, sweet malty, light syrupy nose with nice neutral subtle, light citrussy, green hops. Full bodied, soft smooth, light oily, mouth filling texture. Malty sweets, super clean, easy. Just on the brink of being cloying, hides the abv quite well. Feels like malt candy. Just sweet enough, but with a really clean malt flavour.
Tempting smell. Average head. Fruity sweetness, but less sugar than most doppelbocks. Sturdy hoppiness without exaggeration. Some dark chocolate and lots of malt and bready tones. Complex. Again.
Really liked this. Brown pour with red tint and minimal off white head. Aroma is sweet malt. Taste is sweet malt, nutty and you get a nice warm alcohol feel.

Jam, marmalade, earthy hops, warming and very malty.
Copper colour, medium beige head, lacing. 
Big cloying sweetness, medium bite too sweet for my liking.
Fullbodied, average carbonation, warming finish.
Good example of one of my least favourite styles.
Bottle at home. Clear amber beer with an offwhite head. Malty caramell aroma with nutty notes. Nutty, caramell flavour.
Bottle (bomber) from Systembolaget. Clear chestnut, medium beige head. Bready and nutty malt aroma, some roasted chocolate, herbal hops. Medium bodied, medium carbonation. Dry with medium bitterness.

Flaska från SB. Mahognyfärgad med krämig smutsvitt skum. En dubbelbock i det övre abv-spektrat. Mådde bra av att bli lite varmare, då doft och smak växte och framstod relativt komplex. Len och lite trögflytande lager på lager öl. Maltig, brödig, sädig men också mer mogna söta smaker av torkad frukt smat en lite smutsigare jordig dimension i den annars robusta rustika men också elegant smakbilden. Mycket trevlig.

Bomber courtesy of rlgk. Pours clear copper with a rather small frothy offwhite head that doesnt leave much trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is malty and slightly floral with bread, caramel, hay, moist soil, plums, lemon peal and hints of alcohol. Taste is sweet, bitter, malty and slightly floral with sweet dark bread, toffee, caramel, prunes, hay, moist soil, walnuts, alcohol and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is round, tiny astringent, slightly boozy and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with sweet dark bread, toffee, hay, moist soil, walnuts, alcohol and lemon zest. Possibly but too sweet and slightly too boozy but I quite like it. Nice quite hoppy doppelbock!

Bottle from Systembolaget. Clear amber beer eith a decent offwhite/beige head. Malty nutty aroma, caramel, grainy notes, bready, raisins, toffee notes. Nutty flavor, dark bread, caramel, toffee notes, hay, some warming alcohol, citrus, dark bread, some raisins. Quite nice.
Bottle. Mahogany beer with a light cream head. Toffee and rich malt aroma with light dark fruit. Caramel and toffee flavor with light roast. Medium bodied. Caramel and toffee linger.

Bottle (2014 vintage).

Head is initially small, frothy, off-white to light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is light to medium brown.

Aroma is lightly malty (caramel, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (orange).

Flavor is heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, velvety/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

Not much going on in this rendition, but its at least drinkable.

Bomber pours a clear dark amber/brown with small beige head and not much lacing. Aroma is not strong, but has oak, licorice, cardamom, and lots of bready malts. Taste is sweet at first with a bitter boozy finish. Body is medium to full with a slightly oily mouthfeel and average carbonation. I love doppelbocks, but this one is a bit strong and simple for me.

Bottled:Pours deep, clear amber with a mid sized head.Sweet aroma of red berries, toffee, dark currants and a little bit of licorice.Sweet and sticky mouth feel.Malty flavour with hints of toffee, caramel, syrup and brown sugar leading to a boozy and bitter finish.Pretty good, perhaps a little bit too strong.

Poured from bottle, slightly hazy dark red copper with low off white head. Aroma is mild with notes of caramel, dried fruit, vanilla and butter. Taste is sweet with a big malt body and some bitterness in the finish.

Aroma: Smelling of bread, toffee, cardamom and vanilla.Appearance: A hazy brown colored beer. A low off-white head with small lacing and good curtains.Taste: Tasting toffee, bread, chocolate, grass and vanilla.Palate: Low carbonation, a soft texture. A big body with a slightly dry finish.Overall: Too young, a sweeter less hoppy variant would be better IMHO.Note: Bottle 650 ml at home. Reviewed 2015-01-04.
black color; chocolaty aroma with roasted malt and coffee notes; nice, smooth, chocolaty flavor with roasted malt and coffee notes; very smooth and easy drinking for a beer that weighs in at 9.8% abv
Clear dark bronze pour, small off white head. Nose is malt, leaning dark kilned. Sweet. Middle is molasses, toffee, caramelized malt. Finish is sweet bread with a hint of alcohol. Delicious.

22 oz bottle at home. Pours a hazy brown with reddish highlights and a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have toasted malts, toffee, dark fruits, plums, caramel, earthy hops, smooth, satisfying doppelbock.

Light caramel, toffee & prunes on the nose with moderate malt character. Appearance is a ruby brown with a small off white head with poor retention. Flavor is malty with mild chocolate notes. Prune and plum flavors are also noticeable. Bitterness is high for a dopplebock. Mouthfeel is full with medium carbonation. Overall, it's ok. The bitterness is too high per style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from Bevmo Sacramento. Pours reddish brown with a modest beige head and a toffee aroma. There is a sweet dark malt flavor with a bitter finish. Very malty.

Pours clear dark amber with low off white head
Aromas of dried fruits, caramel, buttery fudge
Taste has butterscotch, caramel, red fruits, wood.

Sweet and floral flavor. The scent felt mostly empty and watery. Is this a defect beer perhaps? Quite so bitter aftertaste that fills the upper part of the mouth for a long while. Easy to drink to have such a high alcohol percentage. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.
Pour dark amber with a foamy off-white head. Caramel aroma. More caramel on the tongue along with dried fruit and a touch of bitterness.

Pours clear deep amber with low off-white head. Aroma of malts, hazel nut, toffee, butterscotch and burnt sugar. Taste is sweet, roasty caramel, hazel nuts and light booze with a burnt butter finish. Body is fairly rich and smooth with soft carbonation.

Bomber from web SB cons 2014-12-13, Lucia - Göteborg
AR: bready, caramel, malt bread, butter fudge when poured
AP: ruby, wee thin reddish white foam
F: rich carbonation, butter fudge, caramel bar, warming feeling, smooth body, medium bitterness -, plums in syrup, finishes buttery caramel

Clear, dark mahognycolored beer with a two finger high, beige head. Lacing stays on the glass when the head dissolves. 

Nose: Plum, apples, raisin, brown sugar, caramel malt and nuts.
Taste: Sweet caramel malt, a LOT of malt! Raisin, toffee, nuts and bread.
Body: Medium to full body with small carbonation. Ligth bitter together with a high malty sweetness. 
9.8% ABV made me think of a alcohol-bomb but its well hidden in the sweet malt. To my suprise its not at all boozy!

Great doppelbock! Not as great as some "original" German versions but still very pleasant!
Rated based on notes taken 24 Feb 2012 -- I really thought this was so-so for a Doppel. Disappointed.
Sample at Örebro Öl & Whisky 2014. Malty smell with roasted sugar and caramel. Similar taste. Sweet and malty with toasted sugar.

Pours dark amber with a low off-white head. Aromas of caramel, rye bread, dried fruit, raisins, slight honey. Taste is caramel, rye bread, dried fruit, butterscotch, raisins, slight honey. Mouthfeel is quite rich and smooth with medium carbonation.

22 oz. bomber from BevMo. It pours a very dark, hazy amber color with a short lived off white head. The aroma has fruity malt notes of plum, pear, apple, some caramel and bread with slight hints of molasses. The flavor is powerful with caramel, rich fruity malts, hints of burnt toast and cocoa with some syrup and molasses in the finish. Theres some discernible bitterness in there as well, but doesnt add much character other than to balance out the big sweet maltiness. Overall, its sweet, caramelly, toasted and bitter in the finish. Not very German in character and hard to drink more than a few ounces.
Draft at oasis. From notes. Loads of caramel and toffee with hints of Roasty malt. Cool.

The aroma is faint, but caramel seems to be the dominate fragrance. A clear mahogany pour with a rapidly dissapating white head and no lacing. The taste, as expected, is very malty, some sweetness, and a touch of alcohol burn with a dryish finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Overall, ok, but there are better examples of Dobblebock out there.
Pours mahogany color with a foamy off white head. Notes of tootsie roll, caramel, earthy cops, sugar cereal, and must. Medium weight mouthfeel with well hidden alcohol.

caramel, nuts, chocolate, roasty, resin, herbs, spruce, alcohol, licorice, raisin, ginger, skunky, smoke, woody, red, clear, white foam, medium sweetness, medium body, fusel, dry, long finish, light bitter,

Draft at RFD. The pour is a nice rubt brown color. The aroma is sweet malt, some toffee and caramel. The taste is nice and flavorful. A very solid dobbelbock. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours brown with red highlights. Nose is surprising; bready, a bit of raspberry, dark malts, maybe a bit of brown sugar. Taste is ridiculously malty, brown sugar, bready, very sweet, a hint of fruity raspberry notes. I don't love the style, it's ok.
Poured a medium brown with a flaky head. Nose of slight malt. Hot in the mouth. Decent lacing. Good for the season, but wont buy again.
Pours reddish brown with a thin off white head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Similar flavors and smooth.

"kinda of a high abv for a traditional doppelbock, but it totally works. Another standout from a solid brewer. loved the light, esrthy hops and the layers of malt in the nose and flavor. VERY drinkable for a strong brew. Thanks heybeerman!"

Pours a beautiful reddish amber with a creamy tan head that mostly lasts. Nose is sweet malt and caramel. Very creamy with a rich soft velvety texture. Taste is bold and full of sweet malt, caramel, maple syrup with just a touch of hops to prevent cloying. An excellent dopplebock that pairs well with smoked cheese or brats off the grill.

Rating from 2010: Auf der Flasche ist ein struppiger, leicht in der Mauser befindlicher Ziegenbock abgebildet - sieht sehr merkwürdig, aber irgendwie witzig aus. Das Bier ist orange-braun und schön trüb. Sehr malzig-schwerer Geruch. Riecht schon sehr gehaltvoll! Der Antrunk ist vollmundig-süffig und sehr schön malzig. Zum Hauptteil wird das Bier komplex-malzig und angenehm süß. Schwerer Körper. Leichte Röstmalztöne. Ganz leicht säuerlich. Dabei auch gelbe Früchte und eine leicht mild-hefige Note. Der Nachgeschmack ist sehr fruchtig-malzig. Lang anhaltend. Ganz leicht süßlich-klebrig, aber nicht negativ auffallend. Dabei auch noch ganz leichte Röstmalzanklänge - in die Richtung eines wenig-süßen Malzbonbons gehen. Alkoholische Schärfe ist nur ganz leicht spürbar.  --> Ein sehr schöner, komplexer Doppelbock! Vielen Dank an Micha!  --> 13+12+13+13 = 12,70

22 oz bomber for 7 bucks. Pours clear dark brownish red with an off-white head. Strong aroma of caramel with fruits underneath. Taste is a lot of caramel and quite sweet. The alcohol is masked pretty well. I really cant taste any. Body is medium, average carbonation. I expected a bit thicker beer though. All in all its pretty good. Not very complex but decent and strong.

Bottle. Smuttonator pours with a ruby red/amber color with a medum sized light tan head. Aroma is sweet, almost sickly sweet with plenty of dried fruits (grapes, plumbs) with a boatload of caramel notes. Flavor is a malt bomb, with a nice undercurrent of dark fruits. Surprisingly, the alcohol is pretty well masked, but with all the residual sugars in this one, it really is noticeable if youre drinking the entire bottle. Share this with friends.

22oz bomber:  This one pours a fairly clear, dark amber/mahogany color.  There was about a finger of a khaki colored head on it that didnt linger long but left some lacing.  This one has a nice nose.  Lots of malts, yet there isnt much sweetness coming through.  Caramel, dark fruits are the main components.  Maybe some toffee also.  The taste is excellent.  A hint of sweetness, tons of malts.  Faint roasted malts.  Smooth.  Overall an excellent doppelbock.
Aroma of mocha. Dark brown coffee color. Strong flavor of coffee and chocolate. Long palate
From a 22 oz bottle shared with Ryan. Pours a light cola with an off white head.  Rich malty aroma.  Flavors of caramel and toffee.  Lovely flavors.

Man this is a delicious beer. This one pours a lovely reddish brown, just a touch dark for the style, with an inch of nice tan head. Aroma is sweet malty goodness. Candy, caramel,and just a little bit of toast. The taste follows right behind the nose. She is bready and a little sweet but not at all cloying. Nice big lager yeast fruit balanced by the lightest of hop presence. This big malty girl is beautifully balanced even if she is big for the style. And no part of that nearly 10% is noticed (until you finish the bomber that is!).

2011 bottle into bockfest mug..ruby amber like color..decent sized head light brownish hue..quite lively carbonation..sweet malt dominates the aroma..followed closely by molasses..toffee..cookie..bit of honey..texture is quite slick..finishes smooth with moderate sweetness and the abv is held in check..quite enjoyable like other smutty big bottles..has some punch with a lingering warmth..
Draft: brown, with a tan head.  Its roasty and caramel in the aroma.  The taste is much the same, but with some grassiness.  Nothing too special, but wouldnt call it bad by a longshot.

22 oz bottle, Whole Foods Columbus.  Hazy, deep, red-brown; 2-finger beige head disappears completely.  Aroma is deep and heavy; sweet, malty, apple, raisin, toffee, bubble gum, yeast.  Flavor rich, sweet, chewy, malty, caramel, vanilla, nutty, grass, a little spicy, and just barely some alcohol warmth in the exhale.  Medium-thick body with more-than-average carbonation; medium coarseness in the bubbles but this really froths up in the mouth; slick, almost oily; barely sticky.  There is virtually no alcohol presence here; well done for a nearly 10% beer.  This one came out of nowhere; -nice- beer, Smuttynose.

Bomber poured into a goblet. Ruby brown with a big tan head that fades slowly, leaving no lacing. Very smooth but bold malt backbone and a nice hit of sweetness that isnt at all overpowering. Nice, very warming amount of booze but very drinkable in the end.
Bomber->stem.  Rusty brown with 1/2 inch light tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, and hops.  Taste is sweet malts, has a lingering alcohol aftertaste.  Too sweet.

2011 bottling.  Drank 2012-11-08.  Deep reddish amber, unclear, fleeting head, no lace.  Aroma is fairly big sweet malt, bread, yeast, fruit, and peppery spice.  Flavor continues these with a fairly bitter and boozy build.  Its a bit syrupy on palate but dries well enough.  Really a pleasant beer for how big it is and an amazing American version of a doppelbock.  Seems true to form though perhaps a bit more bitter a finish than normal...but I like that.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of some generous trader. Thanks! Pours a hazy, dark rust orange appearance wit ha nice, big brown head. Really a rich herbal, noble hoppy, grainy caramel malty, mild white fruit (pear/apple), just a touch bitter aroma. Well carbonated. A bit chewy, molasses, vanilla, rich caramel malty, somewhat spicy, a touch nutty, herbal, grassy hoppy flavor with a light note of chocolate. Quite smooth. This is one of the better American-made doppelbocks that Ive had in a while.

on tap at prohibition pig, waterbury. almost clear medium dark brown with a decent light beige head, some retention, nice lacing. nose of caramel and lightly roasted malts, molasses, raisins, and grassy hops. boozy. average carbonation, medium to full body, some sweetness, nice grassy-earthy finish. smooth and nice. wasnt wowed though.

Amber colored with a modest head.  There isnt a lot going on with the aroma, just a lightly malty, slightly sweet quality thats something like a lighter barley wine.  The taste is malty and a little sweet,  but not overly so.  The finish is crisp with a little bit of tingle.
I really dont get a lot of smell off this one. Its got a nice feel on the palate and not much on the aftertaste. Almost a little sweet, which is interesting...
My kind of beer all the way.  Cannot think of any significant improvements that could be made to it.  The bottle Im drinking from was the last one left on the shelf when I picked it up yesterday : )

A - Pours a fairly clear amber-brown with a finger of frothy khaki colored head. The head fades down fairly slowly leaving behind some lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of rich caramel malts, brown sugar, dark fruits, vanilla, molasses, some bready malts, and some booze.

T - Starts off with a mix of rich caramelized malts and some raisin and other sweet dark fruits. Through the middle, brown sugar and molasses come through with some vanilla and bready malts. The finish is a mix of sweet caramelized malts, dark fruits, bready malts, and some booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth and a bit thick with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Nicely balanced doppelbock with a good strong and complex malt profile.
Bomber poured into glass. Doppelbocks are just too much for me, this one especially. Too sweet and heavy on the malt. Almost impossible for me to drink more then a glass.

22oz bottle, 2010 vintage, shared with Robby. Hazy red / brown color. Thin khaki head. Light, crisp carbonation. Dry finish. Bit of loose lace. Big chunks of yeast on the bottom. Very smooth, rich and robust malts. Aromas of dark fruit, toasty malt. Earthy hops. Light bitter and sweet taste. Nice, rich longer aftertaste. Solid, rich and smooth doppelbock.

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, 2010 release.  Pours hazy reddish copper color with a nice 2 finger fairly dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Some decent spotty lacing on the glass, with a good amount of carbonation streaming up.  Aromas of big raisin, prune, biscuit, toast, molasses, toffee, caramel, nuttiness, earth, light roasted malt, and herbal.  Very nice and well balanced doppelbock aromas with good complexity.  Taste of big raisin, molasses, prune, toffee, biscuit, toast, nuttiness, earth, light roasted malt, and herbal spiciness.  Light spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark fruit, molasses, toffee, toast, caramel, biscuit, nuttiness, roasted malt, and herbal on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice flavor complexity and balance.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a fairly creamy and slick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a moderate warming after the finish.  This was very easy to sip on when I opened it, and it gained a bit more heat as it warmed up.  Overall this is a damn nice doppelbock.  Nice flavor balance and complexity; and pretty smooth to sip on.  Got a little bit boozy as it warmed up, but was still a highly enjoyable brew.

[22fl oz bottle] Dark brown beer with a cream-coloured head. Smooth, sweet chocolate and alcohol on the nose. Less booze on the flavour, it hides the alcohol very well on the flavour. Probably because its so sweet  essentially it tastes something like a hot chocolate (albeit a cold, hot chocolate). Other, nutty, flavours arrive as the aftertaste comes in. Some great balance in there [15052012]
Poured a dark brown with a beige head. Roasty, chocolate, hints of coffee and doughy bread. Smooth on the palate with a mild bitter finish.

Bomber from Sylvain from 2011. Hazy light mahogany with a creamy tan head that disappears quickly but with a quick swirl will come back. Caramel, raisins, grain, semi sweet malts, and alcohol present throughout but especially at the beginning. Moderate carbonation and body, prickly from the alcohol, sweet with a hint of bitter, becomes somewhat dry but alcohol and dried fruit takeover.

Aroma is toffee and malt, really delicious. Poured a beautiful ruby red with a huge off white head. Taste is a sweet nutty raisin mix and a slightly bitter finish. Feels full bodied with a thick texture.

Good doppel. Served at a good temperature with a nice thick, creamy, cream-colored head that slowly settles to a partial thin cover and ring with some lace. Color is a clear orange copper with a few bubble trails. Aroma is malt, brandy, toffee, a little caramel. Flavor is like nose and sweeter today than when I first had it last night and more boozy too. Body is good; ditto carbonation. Finsish is like flavor and has a very mild brandy-like warming. Tasty brau.

Bottle...  Poured deep, brownish, ruby, mahogany, with a light tan head.   Nose had biscuit and cracker malt with some dark fruits.  This was very bread-like.  Dark fruits like grapes, plums and raisins.  Clean finish, hardly any yeast presence.  Big malty body, full palate and texture.  Caramel, toffee, and cereal grains.
Pours a medium brown color with some sugary aromas. Caramel and some grains round out the taste. Pretty sweet name!
Bottle @ SF. Auburn with dissipating head. Smells really sweet and a little metallic. Tastes sweet and boozy. Round mouth feel.

Bottle; hazy brown with small off-white head; aroma-sweet, caramel, raisin, spices, alcohol; taste-medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, sticky, average carbonation, warming alcohol. Great beer.

22oz bottle in a stem glass.  Pours amber/brown with a lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of caramel and cereal malts with a little chocolate and nuttiness, and some floral hops.  Flavor about the same, with a lot of malts.  Smooth texture.  A pretty good beer.

Bottle from riverside market. Pumpernickel brown. Rich malty aroma full of dark bread, spiced with caraway seeds. So it has a lovely combination of rich and dry. Alcohol punch in the finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.  Hazy amber color, small tan head.  Aroma of lightly spiced butterscotch.  Taste is sweet and malty caramel.  Plain.
Pours a clear orange-red with a lively tan head.  Smells of malt, cereal & nuts.  Taste is malty, sweet - a little fruity, a hint of smokiness.  Smooth and easy to drink

Bottle, many thanks to coldbrewky. Mahogany color with medium beige head. Aroma of caramel, toffee, some berries. Taste, toffee, syrup, burned sugar, aromatic hops, alcohol.  Bittersweet alcoholic finish. Good.
A boozy, cloyingly sweet doppelbock that really lacks focus. The brewer clearly cant brew this style.
smooth, malty and strong; nose caramel, butterscotch; taste medium sweetness, almost no bitterness
Draft. Deep amber color. Tastes bready and malty. Abv not present but has a rich flavorful palate like it would be. Pretty good

Appearance:  Pours a translucent dark amber with a thin tan film a top.

Aroma:  Floral notes, maple syrup , leaf compost.

Taste:  Burnt toast, caramelized pear, light but noticeable Euro hop spice.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied peppery carbonation.

Overall: Bold, tasty, and a little off the beaten path compared to some classic German doppelbocks.

Poured from bomber into a pilsner glass. Pours a medium brown color with a nice foamy head.

Well balanced aromas of roasted malts, nuts, caramel and some warm toffee

good depth with a very good feel. Medium/full bodied with good flavors of roast malts, toffee, and nutty flavors

a real quality dopplebock. A good malty side to it and it does the style well

22. oz bottle to snifter. Pours a copper brown color with a soapy off white head that fades to a wispy film and sudsy collar. Aroma is honey, figs; spice and  roasted malt. Taste is spice like cinnamon dark dried fruit  toasted pecans and roasted chocolate malt with subtle signs of coffee and toffee. Palate is medium and sticky with a warming alcohol finish, which is dry. Solid brew with good warming flavor and leaving me wanting more.

2011 bottle purchased in NYC (appears to be bottle conditioned0. Pours with a pretty much clear (first pour), bronze hue (somewhat light in color) body with a large and lasting, tan head. Aromas are very, very estery and fruity for a doppelbock. Somewhat disappointing. Although the yeasty/fruit character is not quite the main character, it is distracting from the malt. Good complexity here. Bready, toasty, marzipan, nutty, maple. Sweet, but in a malty instead of caramel way. Some perceived spicy notes. Lots of malt caramelization. Flavors are a bit sweet, but very malt and complex. Some spicy character. Lots of kettle caramelization, mild burning alcohol on the esophagus, malty, bready, nearly syrupy. Mild dark fruit undertones, fusel, toast, munich and a ton of melanoidins. Dark fruit esters are strong, but the malt is there. Sweet, but not in a caramel way. In fact there is a very, very dry finish. The alcohol sweetness and fusel is a bit too pervasive. Big body, fuller mouthfeel. Medium to slightly fuller bodied. Has its highs and lows both to style and in overall enjoyment. Overall it is a "strong" success.
Way too easy to drink for 9.4%, watch yoself wit dis one. Pretty much all malt as expected, with a slighty roasted note to it.

Amber with small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, baking bread, raisiny background.  Body is not exactly light but somehow thinner than I would expect and with an oily feel.  Flavor is slightly sweet, molasses, grains, minimal bitterness.  Not particularly bad but not really my favorite.
Pour is copper with decent tan head. A nice rendition of a Doppelbock with extra malt. Very smooth.

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor for sharing. Pours amber gold with a small white froth. Aroma has some dark fruits, light spices breadiness, fruit cake, sweet and caramel. Flavor starts sweet with the dark fruits coming out, picking up some Light cocoa and roast, a touch metallic with a somewhat spicy finish. Medium body and a crisp carbonation.

2011 bottle.  Pours a lighter than expected copper with a fine off-white froth.  Aroma is fruity, apple, german character malt, faintly grassy, bit of booze.  Flavor trails off a bit, thin in the flavor, not as much character as one would expect, nice flavors though, boozy and bit metallic, missing some roastiness, lingering bitterness that Im not sure what its from.  Thin, sizzling big carbonation.  A light 10% beer?  Very odd feeling because it is so thin in body, very dry without character, and high in carbonation... I really dont understand this.  Aftertaste of a gin and tonic with light anise bitters.

Dark amber color with a creamy off white head. Aroma is baked bread, sugary caramel malt, and dark dried fruit. Sweet flavor with brown sugar, earthy spice and maltiness. Medium bodied and a nice bitter finish. Good stuff.

Pours a nearly clear, copper tinted brown with a thin, but long lasting beige head. Aroma is cereal grain, toast, caramel, spicy and floral hops, a little roast and sweet hay. Flavor is sweet, chewy caramel, roast, toasted crusty white bread, roast nuts, hay, light raw wood notes,hints of chocolate, wet leaves and lots of rich cereal grain. Palate is on the heavy side with a slick entry, moderate, but sharp carbonation and fairly dry, but slick finish. Very nice beer overall, the palate brings the experience down quite a bit though.

Great beer from a great brewery and no, I dont work there.  Popurs a deep copper with a thick tan head (which sticks around for a while).  As far as appearance, the label is great and the beer looks as good as it tastes.  A winner (anothe winner) from Smuttynose.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2012 Very strong malt aroma, with a bit of white bread in it.  The flavor is very malty with a ton of caramel, while not being too sweet.  Extremely good, not an everyday beer but once in a while this is awesome.

22 oz. bottle.  Dark brown pour with big, thick tan head.  Aroma of caramel, banana bread, toffee, some earthy notes.  Some rum soaked dark fruits, raisins, pumpernickel.  Flavor is rich and strong with dark fruit, almond butter, chocolate and caramel.  Dark fruits, a bit of rum, mild alcohol.  Some Oak-like bitterness.  Nice, strong bitterness.  Full bodied, nice carbonation.  Impressive, strong, smooth doppelbock from Smuttynose.
22 oz bottle.  Pours a hazy caramel-brown, and tastes of bit of caramel as well.  Sorta spicy, sorta caramel-y.  A little bit of dark fruits in it.  Smooth and easy to drink, very good.

Shared bomber at a monthly tasting. Poured to a sampler with a cloudy, brown/amber color, bountiful, off white/light cream head foam, and spots & streaks of clingy lacing. The aroma was toasty malt, with a touch of cocoa, dark fruit, a little spice, and brown sugar sweetness. Ditto on the flavor, with moderate hop bitterness in a better than medium body, and complimented with a warming alcohol presence. A solid Doppel.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 recpd via trade.  22oz bottle  great aroma of malt+  nice dark pour - taste is syrupy sweet - ok at first but after 12 oz; too much honey/syrupy sweetness in this one for me...  does better as it warms up - better in smaller quantity..

Bomber from Wine & Beer Westpark. Pours a slightly hazy reddish color with a thin tan head that fades quickly. Aroma of dark malts, toffee, chocolate, raisins, light toastiness. The taste is toasted malts, raisins, chocolate, caramel, faint hop finish. Medium-full bodied with a bit of alcohol warmth. Nice.

GABF 2011.  Murky hazy brownish orange, with a dense off-tan head.  Aroma of big biscuity malty toffee earthyness, and a touch of dark fruit and cocoa.  Flavor of biscuity toffee, rich earthy complex malt tones.  Off-sweet with a huge body, mild alcohol warmth.

Draft.  Dark reddish-brown in color with a lasting one-finger light beige head.  Nice aroma with caramel, toffee, wood, and dark fruit.  The flavor has a good level of caramel and fruity sweetness that  is appropriate for the style but not cloying at all.  Very tasty and true to style.  Medium full body with a somewhat slick mouthfeel and average carbonation.  Some dryness on the finish.  A great American doppelbock overall.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a amount of head.  Strong sweet malty flavor with a lingering finish.

Thanks to Matt for sharing this bottle - The malt bill tastes exactly like date honey. Some raisins and caramel and toffee candy thrown in for good measure. Complex body, but I cant get over the really nice fruits in this.
cellared 2+ years, flowery earthy nose, roasty marshmallow and cocoa, big flavors but so smooth. a very enjoyable and smooth big beer,

Rich, sweet malt with some nutty notes.  Pours brown with an off white head.  Flavorful bready malt with a slight sweetness.  A rich lingering characteristic finishes it as it goes down smooth while warming you from the alcohol which you can taste at the end.

22oz bottle thanks to AirForceHops 
Appearance: Clear mahogany with a medium sized beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sweet caramel, brown sugar and spices 
Taste: Sweet syrup, caramel and hot alcohols 
OK, but very sweet.

Bomber thanks to Craig. Pours a dark amber color with a large off-white head. The aroma is very sweet caramel and rich malts. The flavor is massive heat and very sweet fruity malts, sugary, dry, some toasted flavors. A bit too sweet and hot for me.

Bottle. Pours dark amber with a big yellow head, excellent lace/retention. Aroma is brown sugar, dark fruit, toffee. Flavor is syrup, grain, earthy/soapy hops. Palate is mildly bitter, still very syrupy sweet. Too much for me.

651mL thanks to tastybeer. The pour is a hazy deep amber to maple with a massive, yellow, rocky, thick head. Infinite retention and big lace. Aroma is heavy/dense brown sugar, molasses, licorice, massive German malt, roasted malt, dark candies. Taste is rich and thick and ultra malt forward with heavy pancake syrup, bran oatmeal, husky grain, licorice, earth. Palate is a bit soapy, mildly bitter, mouthfeel is heavier with non-distracting carbonation. On the ball for style.

Cloudy mahogany appearance with a small beige head and decent lacing.  Sweet, caramel malt aroma with hints of toffee and dark fruit.  Alcohol is apparent almost immediately with the first sip.  Earthy flavors of ripe fruit, toffee and brown sugar with a touch of vegetation in the aftertaste.  Medium-to-full bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a long lingering finish.

Hazy deep amber with dusty tan head. Frothy, but fast fading.  Aroma and flavor are of a caramelized raisin/prune with a spicy hop that is nice its moderation.  Fairly sticky palate, but it become more of a drinker as the glass empties.  Alcohol is well-concealed.  A big doppelbock with some interesting flavor attributes.  A fine interpretation of the style, albeit very strong by traditional standards.

All malt all the time. Deep brown but mostly clear beer with a slightly tan suddy head on it. Could see decent carbination. The aroma is malt lover dream of all the calssics, bread, caramel, whole grains, molasses. The taste carries intot he caramel with some biscuit and even some raisins. Medium sweetness.
dark brown, uber sweet, rich malty caramel nose. Brown sugar and milk chocolate in the nose. Rich malty mouth. Very sweet, but enjoyable

Enjoyed from a 22oz bomber in a stemless wine glass.  The beer pours a nice deep copper color, with a moderate off-white head.  The nose shows deep malt notes; caramel, toasted grain, and just a slight tinge of alcohol come through.  The absolute best of what the style can be.  The palate is unyieldingly malty, showing a level of depth that, perhaps, eclipses even such stylistic pantheons as Ayinger Celebrator.  Bread, caramel, biscuits, toffee, and a depth-adding alcohol.  Carbonation and mouthfeel are dead on.  The finish leaves a lingering note of rich malt.  Overall, easily one of the best doppelbocks Ive been fortunate enough to try.  Ethereal.
Brown pour with garnet hues.  Thin beige head and spotty lace.  Aroma is raisin, figs and anise.   Spicy, malts, toffee, and dark fruit.  hot finish.

Bottle. Light brown (almost tan) color, very cloudy with lots of floaties. Foamy white head.  Light malt and spicy aroma.  Sharp  finish that lasts and keeps the flavor lingering.   Full palate, smooth but the high alcohol warms.
bad aroma, stinky, they have completely missed the point of what a doublebock should be. Bad unnecessary bitter finish

22oz bottle.  Poured a deep coppery amber color with a tan foamy head that settled flat. The smell was light with a bit of sweet malt coming through. The taste was malty with mild sweetness, some dark fruits and some vinous malt and balanced with a light hoppiness. The mouthfeel was smooth and creamy and rich with medium body and moderate carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy red with a thin tan head. Floaties. Scent is sweet malts and rye. Smooth caramel taste with some booze burn.

I cant believe I havent reviewed this one yet.
2008 Bottling sampled 11/30/2008

Pours a deep brown with a beautifully clear ruby tint when held to light. Bubbly two finger head leaves mad lacing on the glass. Smells of caramel malt, some dried fruits and a touch of alcohol. Taste is sweet with malts and more of the dried fruits. Some brown sugar, then a bit of alcohol lingers in the finish as well as a little smoke. Creamy mouthfeel, bubbly carbonation, medium to thick in the body. Great Dopplebock from smutty, I need to put a few more of these away for sure.

Aroma is rich and malty with a nice nutty, rye-ish and toasty undertone - very appetizing. It pours a nice clear mahogany with a thick, frothy, pale tan head. So far, so good. Flavor has a strong rye overtone, a malty core, and caramel, grassy and nutty hints. Yummy! Texture is quite smooth but rough around the edges, leaving a nice tingle and a grassy/rye finish. Recommended!

The aroma is heavy with alcohol, caramel malt, and pine hops. The appearance is deep amber with a medium head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is smooth. Overall a very well made beer that fails to impress.
Very rich flavor with a heavy malty with a syrupy, nutty, spicy taste. A strong finish that is astringent.

Bottle, shared with TylerDurden. Clear deep amber with a robust almond head that shows excellent retention. Aroma is very malty, heaps of bread crusts and toast. Flavour is bread crusts, brown bread, brown sugar, low hop finish. Very nicely malted, very tasty.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Ah, there is nothing that smells quite like a good doppelbock.  Dark fruit, malt, some pleasant yeasty tones.  Opaque brown pour.  The flavor reminds me of European honeycake.  Smuttonator is not sweet for the style - it is more robust than your average DB, with lots of fresh grain and hop taste, plus a little brown sugar.  Good mouthfeel.  Another first rate brew from Smuttynose - the finest brewery in New England.

Grainy horehound aroma. Hazy ochre, thin head. Flavor is dates and cherries primarily, but horehound and cashews are also present. Alcohol is not noticeable. Im not a fan of the style and certainly not this sample.
Pour is a mahogany brown color with a decent sized off white head. Nose is of sugar, sugar, and malts. Taste is similar with a slight warm feeling from the alcohol at the end.

22oz Bottle purchased at Heritage Liquors - Cranston, RI. Enjoyed just above cellar temp. Honey, raw Munich malt, malted milk balls, and unfermented sugars in the nose. Aromatic. Flavors work a little better for me, with strong mineral and pils-malt like sharpness, honey and date sweetness, and satisfying mid-winter warming qualities. Clean, balanced, textured, complex, paler, and satiating.

Beautiful dark brown color. There is an immediate aroma of toffee, caramel, and even an escence of smoke. Flavor is rich in malts and very smooth. Incredibly satisfying roasty and earthy taste. Great beer on a cold winters day.

Bottle thanks to my Secret Santa! Poured a hazy brown with an off-white head that dissipated quickly to the edges. Aroma was malty with notes of caramel, sweet grains and biscuit with hints of light fruit. Flavor began with caramel, and bread with a slight backing earthiness and toffee note.

22oz bomber served in a tulip. Pour was a dark ruby brown with three fingers of off white head with less than average retention and very little lacing. Nose was sweet malts,spices,figs,dates and hints of caramel. Taste was malts,figs,plums,dates just a little bit of warmth comes through from the abv. Good body with a smooth mouthfeel and finishes sweet and malty just like a doppel should be if you ask me. Nothing that blew my socks off but a good solid brew none the the less.

(12 ounce bottle - tumbler)  Ruby brown color with caramel, toffee aroma.  Nose also has notes of butterscotch, dark fruits and bourban.  Tastes of caramel, vanilla, and figs.  Leaves a throat warming scotch like finish, creamy texture, flat carbonation and full body.

Aroma of caramel waffle cone, milk chocolate and nougat. Appearance is ruddy brown with tan head. Flavor matches the nose with a big alcohol finish. Palate is creamy with a big mouthfeel. A very good American Doppelbock.

This made for a nice pint.  Bocky, raisin, caramel aroma.  Dark brew, cruddy Smuttynose label, clever word play on the name, darkish head.  Smooth, but with a kick.  Lots of fruit - raisin/fig/dates, apple, good hopping, dark and delicious.  None of the metal bock twang.  Nice.  Think I got this at Market Square Liquors in Timberlane.
22oz bottle. Pours hazy copper with offwhite thin head. Tangy malt aroma. Malty and crisp flavor - bready and toasty flavor. Finishes malty. Overall, tasty bock.

Deep red amber with persistent frothy, tan head.  Malt bomb aroma, however, primarily caramel - not a great start.  Flavor is also very malty, but borderline cloying.  Caramel, tangy, dark fruit with alcohol that is not well hidden.  Acidic finish.  Gong.

22 oz bottle.  Hazy brown with a beige head.  Nose is toffee and dates with a touch of smoke.  Medium body with a tingle.  As much as the aroma was overly sweet, the taste is too bitter.  Starts with apple and caramel then burnt, earthy and grassy.

22oz bottle, 2010 vintage.  Medium brown color, tan foam.  Aroma of burnt sugar, toasted grain, cola, caramel, oak, and hops.  Strong flavor. Tastes of roast, burnt toasted bread, burnt sugar.  Smooth and dark.
Pours medium brown color with light tan head. Toasted malt, caramel and toffee aromas. Sweet caramel flavor with some toasted malts and a slight medicinal taste. Medium body with average carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small off white head. Nose is prunes with some dates and grape skins. Palate is crisp and clean, with a light fluffiness. Flavors of prunes and grape skins with some light raisins.
In Tap. Bridgeview Sleepy Hollow, NY. Nice dark brown pour with a frothy head. Super flavor. Spice rasin Ginger cinnamon chocolate. Powerful long lasting Palett. Yumm!
Bomber. Pours a murky amber with a slight but creamy tan head. Very complex malt tastes of caramel, raisin, brown sugar, toffee, rum. Good stuff.

2009 bottle from Trader Joes. $4.99. Nice price! A deep reddish-brown brew with frothy tan head. Sweet-alcohol aromas. flavor is deep dark, earthy, raisin-plum notes. Heavy Heavy body. 9.6% hits fast and keeps pounding. Dont stand up too fast! Smooth and drinkable though- very smooth.

Fresh 2010 bomber.  The pour yields a dark, ruddy looking, deep burgundy to plummy-brown colored body.  A moderate, velvety-smooth head of beige foam settles to a thin blanket that lasts for the duration.  A wash of suds leaves behind some minimal, skinny lace flaring.  The nose is what doppelbock is all about, based in super rich, malty caramel, loaded with dark fruity elements, including plums, figs, dates, and raisins.  Those fruits are stewed down and reduced, but their collective sweetness is cut a bit by some chocolate malt roast and hints of toasted toffee.  Hints of citrusy and earthy hops play second fiddle, as they should, but they do bring a nice sense of balance to a beer that could have otherwise gone too far into saccharine territory.  Flavors continue the theme, again showing deliciously toasted caramel and toffee notes amidst hints of slightly chalky cocoa, dried plums, prunes, and caramelized dates.  A touch of brown sugar and some dark raisin for good measure round out the fruit profile.  Distant orange peel offers a touch of citrus-based oiliness, and some earth-borne hops add a touch of spicy bite and balance (though it remains largely malt driven and sweet).  The palate sports a smooth, creamy consistency that is supported by ultra-fine, active carbonation.  It drinks pretty easy for a 10% brew, though its ample substance leads in to a mildly sticky finish.  It could be much worse, however, as the carbonation dries things out fairly well.  Very good brew....bordering on excellent, and certainly top notch for the style.  Smuttynose continues on as one of the best, most consistent breweries across a wide variety of styles, yet they get very little pub.

Thank you to my wife who brought this home from a trip. 
Dark Amber in color, clear with a thin head.  Nice malt and light floral hops aroma.  The malts where roasty, sweet and light with floral hops.  This was a tasty brew.
11/23/10.  Bomber.  Sweet condensed/caramelized sugar aroma with a hint of bread.  Sweet caramel and malty flavor with a hint of grainy bitterness in there.  Really not bad!

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - 22 oz bomber. Dark orange to light amber pour, slightly murky with a thin but sticky off-white head.  Sweet aroma with molasses, brown sugar and a wee bit of rum. Flavor is full-bodied and belly-warming. Nice caramel undertones, molasses, dates, raisins and toffee make this a delicious treat. Thickish, rich mouthfeel. Would be good on a cold winters night.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Buy Rite - Jersey City, 11/20/10


Aroma: Caramel malts, brown sugar, molasses, raisin, chocolate, ripe fruits, and a little booze

Appearance: It pours a cloudy brownish-red color with a small beige head and light lace

Flavor: The taste is rather sweet up-front, some sugary notes, caramel, and a little earth

Palate: The body is medium-full, it has a thick/chewy feel, and good amount of heat in the finish

Overall Impression: 
I like this one, a very solid Doppelbock from Smutty.  It has a solid flavor to it, and a little bit of booze giving it a nice finish.  I enjoyed drinking this one.

Pours an orange copper with one finger of creamy light tan head. Nose is rich and malty, sweet and dextrinous, caramel with notes of toasted grain and herbal hops. Flavor is rich with grain and caramel predominating. Notes of toast and herbal hops with a dextrinous character. Palate i a bit sharp.

On draft in a shaker. Ruby red pour with a one finger tan head. Strong aroma of cherries, plums, figs, and raisins. Lots of caramel sweetness. Taste is less bready than other doppelbocks Ive had. Focus is largely on the dark fruits, but there is also a bunch of caramel malt sweetness, and definitely some chocolate. Maybe a hint of toasted nuts. Chewy palate, not exactly an easy drinker. Very tasty, best enjoyed on an empty stomach.

Bomber from Oak Tree. Gonna try the "automated" rating clicky things. amber, hazy, frothy, Obviously a bit awkward. Those were appearance clicks. roasty, butterscotch, Those were aroma. medium sweetness, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, Those were palate. Its a fairly sweet, roasty beer. Think theres some hop in it. Its almost spicey. Damn tasty.

22oz bottle.  murky brown, muddy, beer with a very small beige head.  aroma has lots of caramel and smutty notes.  flavors of smut and stuff.  caramel flavor mostly.  medium body with snappy carbonation and alcohol.  not my favorite.

Bomber.  Pours hazy dark reddish copper with a large frothy light brown head.  Dark fruity malt aromas of cherry, raspberry, and plum.  Molasses, toffee, and caramel are also present.  Flavor is deep and malty with sweet cocoa and berry, slight grassy hops, and very slight toasty coffee.  Rich, warming, low/medium carbonation, creamy, and dry.  Very nice malty beer.

From the 2010 batch.  The pour is an amber-brown with about a finger ofr silky off-white head and good, clinging lacing.  The aroma starts off on the malty side and then there is a kind of stronger alcohol sensation a moment later.  The body is solid.  The taste also highlights the malts with a sort of hard liquor combination on the backside and a raw sugar sweetness.  It seems to fit the bill of the style.
Draft at mff with pat. Pours a hazy amber brown body with creamy brown head. Aroma is nut and caramel malt. Smooth Mouthfeel with nutty and wheat notes.

650 mL bottle.  A lovely ruby-brown colour with some sediment and a huge orange-brown head.  Smells the part, with a big malty aroma.  Typical caramel and nuts of a doppelbock, with humbugs, white grape juice, and some dried fruit at the end.  No alcohol presence at all.  Incredibly smooth.  One of the best doppelbocks Ive tried.

On tap @ Smuttynose. Dark garnet pour with a white head. Heavy malt aroma with some fruit. Taste is very bold with malt and fairly complex with lots of little flavors that come through in the aftertaste. Nice creamy mouthfeel, got a lot of peach flavor, nice brew.

22 oz. bottle from from lb4lbs liquidation extravaganza (3 of 3)- served in tumbler (75 limited was exposed here)- somewhat transparent dark brown (ohh, Im shaking...), aroma of beer, malt, hops, water, caramel, molasses.  Hits mouth with high medium body, malt was aged after brewing, but there, middle is fine, finish reminds me of a Hartford cathouse- its there for a reason, and you really dont want to know why, but you go just to RELEASE... finish- Ive had better.  Yep, sure did.  Thanz Deniz!
Pours deep brown with huge tan head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, malts, slight soy. Drinks sweet with loads of dark caramel, and lightly burnt malt. slight bitter bite on the finish. Very thick bodied.

Bottle.  Pours almost opaque chocolaty brown with an off-white head which rapidly deflated to a thin layer of cream.  The aroma is rich, toasty, some oak, molasses.  Flavor profile is complex, notes of coffee, ripe fruit, smokey oak, molasses.  It has a thick rich body, a sweet smooth lasting finish with just a touch of a zing in the back palate.

Aroma is barley and oaky red wine. Roasted malts. Sugary but not saccharine. Bourbon-ish aroma. 

The appearance is uber-cloudy mahogany brown-red. Resilient head and huge gobs of lace glows from within. One of the best-looking beers EVER.

Heavy brown sugar taste, with an earthy soil-tinged malt. A mild, woody (oak) hop. Barleywine territory. Toffee and molasses at the swallow.

Feels smooth and buttery. A hefty, smooth double bock. Earthy and bittersweet. Very very solid.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with a moderate tan head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of rich malt, sweet caramel along with just a bit of butterscotch.   The flavor is similar to the aroma, except there is a noticeable alcohol presence in the flavor that detracts slightly.  A bit lighter in body and not quite as full in terms of mouthfeel as I enjoy in a doppelbock.

Dark red body, thick foamy beige head. Aroma- dark fruit and alcohol, vanilla, brown sugar, citrus, roast malt. Taste is balance of bitter and sweet with a bitter and roasty finish. Very thick body and lots of flavor in it.

NOTCHED ON LABEL: Bottle-conditioned in 2008

Brown liquid with a beautiful dark ruby tint. Hella huge head of light brown foam. Excellent retention and fantastic lacing.

Nice big molasses nose with a good malty presence. Good caramel presence, also. Slight hint of citrus hops. An element of fresh bread. 

The molasses flavor is right out front, and quite prominent. Big yeasty breadiness. Good dark fruit presence. Mostly raisins, figs and even some notes of dates(!). Very nice rich maltiness. Hints of rich caramel and mild chocolate. Very slight hint of hop notes. Finish has a little bit of pepperiness in it.

Great full body. Nice and thick, almost chewey. This is how I like a beer to feel in my mouth. Very creamy and tasty.

For 10%ABV, this is a deceptively smooth and easy drinking brew. Id have no problem drinking multiples or recommending that others do the same.
On top of all of that, I am a fan of the Double Bock/Dopplebock style, and this is a top ten, for me. Probably even a top five.
Very well done, Smuttynose!
Looks exactly like the Smutty Scotch I just finished. Really?  I say they used to same wort for both the scotch and doppelbock. The dopplebock is basicly the same. Just a bit cleaner.

Fabulous Dobbelbock!  Dark garnet pour with a white head.  Heavy malt aroma with some fruit.  Taste is very bold with malt and fairly complex with lots of little flavours that come through in the aftertaste.  Fruit, chocolate, yeast.  Full body that just pleases.  I adore this beer and will be on the hunt for more.

[2434-20090809] Bottle. Heavy yeast and fruity malt aroma. Murky, dark brown amber body with a long-lasting creamy light tan head. More heavy malt in the flavour with toasted yeast and a long sweet malty finish. Full body. Really tasty, a great start to our own rendition of a Toronto Beer Fest.
(@ Beerfest at the Condo; w/ DuctTape, jerc, others)

A deep hazy red-brown pour with a thick and lasting light tan head with awesome lacing.  Aroma very malty with light fruit notes, caramel richness, and even chocolatey notes.  Rich sweet malty flavor with just a bit of alcohol as well.  A mild bitterness on the end as well.  Very thick beer that feels like a meal in a bottle.  I am a big fan.

2008-08-09. Hazy brown body with a good sized tan head. (4+) Sweet malty aroma, caramel, very light fruity touch. (7+) Flavour is very malty, sweet caramel, dry malt and moderate bitterness in the finish. Smooth average plus bodied palate. Warming alcohol in the finish grows as you go. Quite enjoyable. Bottle from Premier Gourmet

Thanks me!  Murky muddy brown with some floaties.  Burnt raspberry and charcoal.  Dense and creamy, roasted beautifully, magical and brilliant.  Late in the tasting session where the description becomes less substance and more emotion.

22. thanks, scrizzzz! pours cloudy dark brown with caramel highlights. dense creamy tan head. big sweet caramel nose, some alcohol there as well. creamy medium body, plenty of carb. caramel and sharp boozy mid palate. long dry finish.

bottle
pours dark brown, mocha head, golden lacing on glass.
aroma is malty, chocolate, some dark fruits; cherry.
taste, caramel malts, chocolate notes, some barnyard palate, hoppy, some notes of plums, cherries, dry grains, caramel with a light bitter bitterness, spices and some grassy notes.
Bottle. Hints of chocolate in the nose with a touch of maltiness. Flavor has a bittersweet chocolate taste, low amount of hops and incredibly smooth despite the alcohol %.
Bottle.  Pours a dark brown body with a tan head.  Sweet malty caramel body with a fruity chewy etoh latent fruit.  Plum, nut and apple.  Nice brew.

2006 Bottle sampled July 2009 shared with the guys at the Barrios 500th Swallow Tasting.  Beautiful hazy plum pour with coolaid red highlights and good offwhite head.  Nose of plums and other rum soaked fruits with a small hint of mellow alcohol.  Alcohol is a bit more hot on the flavor, with caramel, plum, and other dark fruits. A hint of molassis. Cool name, but I really dont care for these smutty labels that much.
2006 bottle conditioned.  Pours a ring of beige head with a copper body.  Smells of caramel and figs.  Tastes of dried fruit and alcohol.  Nice, fizzy carbonation.  Finish lingers with some vanilla.

Tap at the Ginger Man NYC:

Very dark red with a cream-a-licious head.  Over rich on the nose. Very boozy with hints of rosemary and balsamic vinegar.  Kinda woody and a little sickly. In the mouth it is very rich and meaty with slight chocolate characters.  Some caramel too with deep plums and some rhubarb. Quite deep but a maybe overbearing to begin with.  Pretty tasty once you get into it.

2008 bomber sampled february 2009...

pours like dark dr. pepper with a lasting hot cocoa colored head and some drippy lacing. 

the nose is very malty and has notes of brown sugar, chocolate, a nuttiness which is not quite coffee-like, grassiness and some fruit... raisins and sweet cherries. 

the flavor reminds me of eating bananas and coffee with malted chocolate milk in it... malt powder, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, toasted nuts, molasses and floral alcohol which, to me, tastes like bananas... coffee is all over the aftertaste. 

the medium body has a creamy mouth feel, a pleasant acidity and sharpness. it is quite dry from the alcohol which also warms the belly. the sweetness does get bothersome toward the end of the glass... 7/4/7/4/14/3.6

Bottle at local BA gathering.

Poured clear red brown color with a large frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing.  Good caramel toasted malt, tart citrus and yeast aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Good balanced bittersweet malty flavor with a moderate to heavy smooth balanced finish of moderate to long duration.

Standout doppelbock.
22oz bottle. Pours dark brown with full foamy brown head. Aroma sweet, caramel and roasted malt. Taste caramel, molasses and roasted malt with bitter finish.

22oz bottle courtesy of MrRetardedMonkey poured into a pint glass.

Pours a deep, slightly hazy amber with a big creamy tan head that sticks to the sides of the glass stubbornly and stays on as a cap for the duration.

The smell is dominated by sweet caramel malts and lots of dark fruits as well.  Theres also some citrus hop burn in the nostrils as well.

The taste is again dominated by the caramel malts with some molasses coating the mouth throughout.  The hops are present but very subtle in the taste.  There are raisins and figs before a sweet slick finish.

The mouthfeel is slick and sticky with the sweetness of malts and dark fruits.  The soft carbonation is very complimentary to the full bodied mouthfeel.

This a big, fairly heavy dobblebock that is quite a sipper for the style.  Its not the best representation of the style but its got some unique twists that make it interesting.

Thanks to Maltomeal for this beer. Reddish dirty brown pout with a big tan head. Nose of winter spices, nutmeg and woody notes. Flavor is prunes, raisins and spices. Chewy and layered. Really good Doppelbock that lingers.

Bottle. Pours a slighlty hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Has a malty spicy yeasty aroma with some hints of dark fruit. Sweetish malty spicy yeasty caramel flavor. Has a sweetish malty spicy caramel finish.

Poured this bomber into my large Pilsner glass the body was a hazy burgandy in color. The big foamy of white head seemed to last the whole beer

Big and malty nose on this thing, dark fruits follow as she warms up. The flavors are malt forward, sweet molasses raisins and figs. The thing is I get no warmth from this, and at 10% I am surprised medium feel in the mouth with good carbonation.

Good drinkability on this quite a relaxing one to drink but you do feel the alcohol in the end. Ill grab another one to cellar for longer next time

22 oz. bottle - thanks for tweety for the bonus; pours dark brown with slight haze and reddish glow against the light; frothy, light tan head; aromas of syrup, maple, caramel and dank fruit; lots of dry, rich malt with slight spice; quite dry and really opens up as it warms; alcohol is obvious and 2nd glass was an absolute delight

22 ounce bottle in Paulaner half litre.  Brownish red with lasting fluffy head and lotsa crap floating in it.  toasted caramel and woodsy port aroma.  Toasted caramel mild fruit and woodsy flavor.  Medium-full body.  NIce texture.  Kinda like a doppelbock barleywine.  I tried to find something wrong with this (other than the floaters), but I couldnt  Rich and luxurious, tasty enticing....and strong.

Bottle.  Began the pour as a clear amber, but by the time I was done with it, it was hazy deep brown bordering on opaque.  Large light beige head.  Particulate matter in suspension.  Sweet  malt, yeast, toast, caramel.  Sweet, with a bit of stone fruit, and complex malt.  Alcohol sneaks up at the end of the finish for a nice warming note.  I quite like this one, to the point that Ive actually bought it more than once.

From bottle. Has a pretty sweet nose to it, with nice malty brown sugar and light caramel. Mild bitter hops in the nose, with a light astringent metallic whiff. Oxidated Tootsie Rolls and bitter citrus pith, fruity esters. Dark ruby brown with medium foamy lacing off-white head. Medium-heavy watery body with medium carbonation. Starts sweet with lots of caramel, brown sugar, and candi sugar. Loads of viscous sugary malt with browned notes. Dry nutty-sweet bitter finish with neutral hop flavor. Good bittering that prevents this from being cloying. After is sweet and leaves some sugar lingering at the back of the throat. Light bittering on the front of the tongue. Overall, a decent doppelbock.

Thanks to mcox90 for this one!

I really like the name of this beer.  It pours a very deep burgundy, with tan head, lovely.  The aroma is of sweet malts, overripe fruit, and some roastiness.  I get flavors of sweet malt, caramel, and brown sugar.  Mouthfeel is thick and creamy.  Overall a pretty good beer.

Red-brown with a small brown head.  Aroma is sweet malt, cane sugar, caramel, dark fruits and nuts.  Flavor is sweet, its a malt bomb with a slight hop profile in an attempt to balance the massive malts.  I actually enoyed this brew even though Im more into hops.  Mouthfeel is rich and thick which makes the brew smooth to drink.  Alcohol is present but not overwhelming, maybe the age has toned it down a bit.  Finish is a little syrupy and sweet.

Bomber - Poured a very dark brown in color with a foamy tan head that hung around and provided some nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma is very malty and sweet with hints of some hops, dark fruit and plenty of  caramel/toffee.  Flavor is plenty sweet with some alcohol present.  Dark fruit (raisins, dates, prunes), hint of vanilla and slightly bitter as it finishes.  Too much alcohol in the profile... not too much alcohol (I like), but not well hidden.  A good effort...

Dark pour, nice two finger head and lacing that left its presence in the mug.  Overly sweet, bordering on sickly.  Some nice ashy burnt notes which helped this out.  My Salt & Vinegar chips helped the sweetness tone down.  It was a mistake to drink this whole bomber myself.  I could have appreciated this more in a smaller dose.
reddish brown color, nice foam. nose is nutty, some vanilla, a little roasted malt and alcohol, flavor is same except for a little fruityness nice beer.

Bomber.  Murky mahogany/brown pour with a lovely tall, lasting tan head, rich and creamy, rocky and lacing.  Molasses and toffee malt, faint brown sugar.  Taste is much the same, but with a ton of alcohol showing - too much, really.  A little extra heft.  Dark earthy tones with faint spice.  Good, but the constant straining for "big beer" status really hurts a lot.

Pours light brown with a fluffy white head.  Malts dominate the aroma, with whiffs of caramel, raisins, and alcohol.  Flavor is similar but has a tad too much alcohol.  Palate is a little fizzy and lively at first, but becomes very smooth once this beer warms.

Bomber shared by theisti at a Chiefs tailgate. Pours a hazy caramel brown with a creamy beige head and chunky sediment. The nose is of sweet caramel and toffee with an overriding, solid, round maltiness. On the light side of medium-bodied and creamy with a lightly tinny and tight finish. The flavor follows the nose with solid notes of caramel and toffee. This is a very nice doppelbock. Thanks again for sharing it with us, Tim.

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of dark bread and nutty, light perfume for the hops, light to moderate dough and earth for the yeast, with toffee, brown sugar, dried cherry, spice and bourbon in the background. Head is large, creamy, off-white with excellent lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is murky brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, creamy and chewy almost syrupy and has a lively carbonation. It finishes dry and a little astringent. A great balance in flavors and a rich texture makes this an exceptional Doppelbock.

The aroma is a pleasing mix of malts, toasted grains, and dark fruits, maybe some molasses. The appearance is true to the style, an attractive dark red/purple/brown, with a steady tan head. The flavor is, like many dopplebocks, a nice sweet, fruity flavor, malts, bready. The mouthfeel is appropriately thick for the style, and the finish has a mild bittering from hops. Well crafted beer overall.  Nice representation of the style.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Aroma is caramelized malts, vanilla, a little alcohol bitterness.  Pours dark brown, thin beige head, significant lacing.  Flavor has rich malt complexity: malt syrup, caramel, vanilla, nuts, but its cut by a significant medicinal bitterness that takes the pleasure out of it.  Smooth, but syrupy cloying on the palate.

22 oz bottle courtesy of mcox99. Pour is very unfiltered cloudy brown with visible chunks. Aroma of earthy slight ash, some fruit sweetness taste is the nose, with a very unfiltered body. Palate is full.  I loved the depth and complexity of this beer.  Nice one.

Pours a dark brown almost black with a very thin head. Smells heavily of Malt and some coffee, chocolate, raisin and alcohol. Tastes of  sweet malt, plum, raisin, prune and coffee. Palate: : sticky syrupy sweet. Makes lips stick together. Nice warming alcohol finish. Very drinkable, but more of a one beer sit and sip for a long duration

Bomber from Phhd.  Pours dark orange with a 3 finger tan head.  Nose is sweet and slightly malty.  Taste is sweet malty and overall quite good.  This is a great dopplebock.  Lots of flavor, lots of complexity.

Bomber, drank all by my lonesome. This one makes me #1 for Smutty, woohoo! Suck it, JoeMcPhee! Sometimes after drinking this much of a single beer, something that was otherwise dull starts to shine, and complexities begin to reveal themselves. Other times, something that was OK at first starts getting really dull and tired, and one doesn’t even want to finish it. This beer is of the latter category. The aroma is vegetal, beety, some nyc street vendor potato knish, some white sugar. The flavor is sweet and syrupy, with a very thick body, but it is hard to enjoy it more than perhaps small quantities. This is a bit too much double of a doppelbock. Really just overwhelming in most regards. I’m not too crazy about this.

Style and Glass: Doppelbock; mug, stein, stem glass
ABV, Volume & Calories: 8.5% in 22 fl oz. estimated at 400 C
Purchased at: Canals Lawrenceville, NJ for $5.89

Aroma: nice, syrup, maple, mold, rose, citrus.

Visuals: interesting packaging, iced tea, reddish brown, slightly hazy, off white long lasting head, intricate lace.

Taste: well balanced, high malt, medium hops, medium high strength.

Palate: high quality, spicy, scratchy, dry, longer drying finish.

Overall: A very well done beer, and one of the few doppelbocks Ive truly enjoyed. If they were all like this, I might like the style more. Id have this again, though its not what Id call a favorite. High value for a well crafted brew.
2006 gusher, garnet gold color with a filmy head, aroma of spiced fruit, good chocolate and raisin flavors with some blue cheese on the finish

Smuttynose Smuttonator 10/31/08 (bottle.  Pours dark brown, with little head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, and chocolate.  Flavor is full-bodied, rich, and very tasty.  There are strong chocolate notes present, blended with some wood.  As is stylistically predictable, Summtonator has little hop profile to be detected.  Nonetheless, a very tasty brew that faired well in my beer tasting amongst friends.

bottle thanks to mcox90.  Shared at October Houston Tasting.  Pours a dark brown with a thin, off-white head.  Nose is of cinnamon bread and caramel malt.  Taste is of cinnamon bread and roast malt.  Mouthfeel is sweet and thick.

Bottle from MaltOMeal at the Houston tasting.  Thanks!>br>Pours a cola-thin brown with a carbonated head to match.  Nice aroma of cinnamon, nutmeg, and sugar.  Nice chocolate molasses and syrup flavors surrounding a sweet cinnamon roll.  Nice, thick mouthfeel.  GREAT beer!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Malty and a robust fruit aroma. Medium tan head and burgundy color. Mild beginning with a grapish finish. Silky palate.

Bottle. Pours ruby brown with a lasting beige head. Toasty malt aroma with chocolate and caramel sweetness. The flavor is also toasty malt with a light raisin-esque fruitiness, as well as chocolate and caramel. A fair amount of hops show up in the finish, which I really liked. Very good.

Opaque brown with a thin brown crest of head. Aroma is sweet and raisiny with port like notes... rather barleywine.   Taste is sweet pumpernickel and tangy raisin.  Very rich and substantial with mildly tannic oaky aftertaste. $6/22oz

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malts, caramel, rye, beans, and sweet malts.  Poured cherry-wood brown with a hint of ruby in color and a medium-sized, dense head that lasted throughout.  Sparkling.  Very hazy.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malts, caramel, light toasting, resin, tar, raisins, hops.  Medium to full body.  Viscous texture.  Average carbonation.  Smooth, malt, raisin and resin finish.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Pours a deep chestnut brown color. Roasted & sweet malt aroma. Notes of chocolate. Sweet tasting, boozy, brandy. Fuller bodied. Rich. One big beer

Bottle. Aroma of soda and honey, yuck. Thankfully flavor wasn’t quite as soda-laden, with some cookie dough malt jumping in, but still extremely sweet. Mouthfeel of carbonated syrup. Not as disgusting as the aroma led me to believe, but no good either.
