Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt and soda.  Flavor of raisin bread, yeasty pizza dough, spices, and soda.  Reminds me of expired Corsendonk Christmas Ale, hehe.  A little too sweet with a weak palate.  Probably most similar (in terms of doppelbocks) to Spaten Optimator.
A deep and rich dark lager, a la Ayinger Celibrator.  Maybe a bit too sweet for my tastes, as is common with these strong bocks.  Thick and velvety palate.

Pours deep black with a GREAT head and some fabulous lacing. Good looking beer typical of a what I expect from a doppelbock. Flavor is dark, smoked, with a bit of alcohol bite at the end. A slight tinge of malty, coffee, roastedness. I didn’t find any real fruit in there. Pretty plain doppelbock that doesn’t try to do all that much but succeeds admirably in what it shoots for. Creamy, smooth palate. Very enjoyable brew. My father raved about it.

THOUGHTS: Nice doppelbock, but an odd time of year for this release. Just the right amount of alcohol in the nose and on the tongue for that wonderful doppel small and taste. Not a huge Smuttynose fan, but this was dead on to they style. Above average doppel. Taste was way more complex than the nose.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark, brownish garnet, but bright red when held to the light with a large to huge, foamy, tan head that slowly diminished, keeping a nice sheet and leaving good to excellent lacing that was thick but a little sparse. The aroma was heavy cookie, molasses and caramel malts; slight cocoa; raisin, cherry, alcohol, sherry, brandy. The initial flavor was moderate to heavily sweet, and lightly acidic and bitter; while the finish was lightly sweet and moderately bitter with an average duration. There was cherry, tobacco,  burnt caramel, sherry, brandy, alcohol, raisin and slight cocoa. The medium body was somewhat syrupy (sticky on the lips), yet also oily with lightly fizzy carbonation and a light alcoholic finish.

Brown caramel pour with serious head.  Caramel malty notes come off the top with a souring and assertive hops piney quality.  LIght barnyard, with sticky caramel notes, sugary, syrupy.  Very smooth and drinkable on the palate and this masks the alcohol stealthily.  Tooth coating in its almost maple syrupy nature, yet it is balanced by some stange anti-matter quality which i cannot identify.  Good brew.

2004 vintage received via trade with sloth.  Pours dark brown with a spare, fizzy, light brown head, mostly diminishing with no lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (biscuit, cookie, bread, nutty), heavy hops (perfume, flowers), average yeast (dough) with notes of alcohol, pear, dates, apples, and brown sugar.  Full bodied, sticky texture, average carbonation, and a spicy finish.  Long duration, heavy sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

Bottle 08’.  Deep brown pour with a lasting thick beige head.  Malts and sweetness in the nose.  The flavor is carmel, malt, sweet baked goods, vanilla, and buscuits.  very sweet and full bodied.  well concealed alcohol.
Cloudy orange colour with an off white head. Alcohol and vanilla sweet aroma with a light hoppy note. Caramel sweet and fruity flavor with a vague hoppy note.

Dark brown, the color of a chocolate lab. The head was thick and brown, leaving a substantial lacing.

 The aroma was malty on a background of sweetness. The result was caramelly but not quite caramel.

 The flavor was a bit short lived. The carbonation was nice but rushed the malty sweet tones and rushed to a metallic aftertaste.

 Overall warm and certainly above average.
22 oz. bottle. Poured a cloudy red with a very subtle nose. Very creamy tan head. However, flavor was a bit too sweet and raisiny for my taste. Very yeasty, rich mouthfeel.

(Bottle).  Malty sweet aroma.  Color a dark reddish brown, with a moderate creamy tan head.  Flavor is attractively complex, although a little sweeter than I expect in a doppelbock.  Some fruit, lots of malt.  Good mouthfeel.  Nice effort, but not up to the standard of Celebrator.

pours a dark garnet with really nice bubbly head. Aroma is fruity, sweet, with caramel and some citrus. Flavor is delicious- some yeast quality, cider, fruit, and malt. Palate is delicious. Great offering from Smuttynose, go NH.

Shared with craftycarl21- thanks Carl. Pours dark reddish brown with lively, and somewhat large head. Aroma is caramel, orange, and lighter sweet fruit. Some dark fruit in there as well. Biscuit, and malt character powerful. Flavor is tons of caramel, ripe fruit, cider, and huge maltyness. Palate is smooth and full. I’m proud to live in New Hampshire- Smuttynose kicks ass.
Bottle. A dark amber beer with a big beige head. The aroma and taste is of caramel, rye bread and hops. Medium body with a light alcoholic finish.
Hazy dark amber with medium beige head. Sweet fruity aroma with hoppy and caramel notes. Sweet fruity flavor with hoppy and caramel notes. Ends bitter.

(Bottle 65 cl) Courtesy of BrianK. Pours a hazy reddish amber colour with a dense off-white head. Aroma of caramel and overripe fruit. Quite full-bodied with sweet caramel, fruit and aroma hops. The finish is bitter with quite some alcohol presence. 260708
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2008 Amber colour. Aroma of dark fruit, malt - sweet. The flavor is dark fruit, alcohol and with a bitter aftertaste to balance it all.

Poured a hazy brown color with a large off white head. Aroma was very sweet, soem dark fruits, and alcohol. Flavor was extremely smooth, nice and sweet dopplebock, hides the alcohol very well, a bit fruity also.
Bottled - tasted blind. A hazy dark amber beer with a thin tan head. The aroma is sweet malty combined with notes of caramel and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, and alcohol.

From bottle #13 at sk8vikings American blind tasting. Pours hazy deep amber with lacing light tan head. Spiced and hoppy aroma. Light caramel malt note. Roasted and toffee flavour. Warming alcohol. Lingering dark caramel malt. Fruity finish.

#13
Bottle [Sk8viking great American blind tasting] Average creamy beige head that mostly lasted. Fair display of lacework. Cloudy amber color. Aroma of lovely peach and apricot, vinous and toffee. Over the palate came bread, alcohol, dry wood. Medium to full bodied with an average carbonation and dry alcoholic texture. Moderated to heavy sweet flavor with good counter sweetness. Lingering hoppy finish. 7 / 3 / 7 / 4 / 15 = 3.6

brownish ruby pour with a full offwhite head.  Strong sweet malts in the nose, perhaps caramel.  Sticky malt taste,  chewy mouthfeel is wonderful.  dark fruits of over ripe dates and figs.  malty and delicious.

Bottle acquired via jjpm74...THANKS John!!!    Deep garnet with a dense off-white body.  The aroma is toffee, caramel and brown sugar.  Flavor is extremely malty with dark fruit and noticeable alcohol.  A big beer.

2006 bottle.

Appearance: Pours a clearish, ruby-hued body topped by a full, though short-lived yellowish head.

Smell: Strong maltiness in the nose, with a full scent of luscious toasted caramel. Figs and plums provide some fruitiness. Hint of breadcrusts and booze.

Taste: Rich, toasty caramel maltiness with a big sweetness. Touch of light aniseed, a drizzle of fruit-flavored syrup. Only a slight hop bitterness. Hint of ripe red apples near the sweetish finish. Taste of toasted grain lingers into the aftertaste. The alcohol is present, sure, but nothing to fuss about.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Very nice doppelbock from Smuttynose. Full of malts and plenty chewy without ever wandering into syrupy territory.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2008 *did not like would not buy*

aroma: clean booze. sweet mild malts. brown malts nannners. real mild. app: beautiful warm rich glowing color. magic.  flavor: warm nutty buttery malt goodness. kinda sharp booze. some acidic hops in the finish, they seem odd and out of place . they hops grow and grow and get out of balance, this is more like a good DIPA.  way outta line.  palate: fine to fizzy.  OA: was good till i got hop hammered. then boo!

Large bottle   Poured a thick off white head , decent lace.  Aroma of malty, caramel  flavors of toffee,maple and caramel. Oiley mouthfeel and a little bitter at the finish.  Alcohol is noticeable but not overpowering.

Bottle - pours a deep amber with a tight foam that quickly falls into a skim of light bubbles.  Aroma is malt and alcohol.  Caramel, toffee and booze dominate the nose.  Flavor is similar with plenty of malt, caramel, toffee with a spicy hoppy note before the light fruity  & alcoholic dry finish.  Medium body.

Pours a very dark brown with thin beige head.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate maltines and tofee.  Very quaffable beer with the high abv very well hidden.  Flavor consists of caramel, roasted malt, chocolate brown sugar, cinamon and toffee.  Sweet dry finish.  Excellent.

Deep amber color with a big, fluffy tan head that lasts and leaves sticky foam on the side of the glass.  Nose of brown sugar sprinkled over malted milk balls.  Very sweet, malty beer.  Lots of melted toffee, lightly burnt caramel, malt syrup, and some fruitiness to balance it out.  This is a tastey Double Bock, and is very easy to drink for a 9.6% ABV.
Bottle. 2006. Nice dark brown pour with a medium head. Very nice aroma of nuts and malt. Very nice and complex taste. very warming with a great after taste.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2012 2006 bomber. Really fine stuff for a chilly night. A deep ruby color and a sizable head on the pour, this beer gives off a fine nutty aroma thats quite promising. The flavor is deep and complex, with strong caramel, a hint of tart fruits, and a long malty finish. Nice body, a very nice doppelbock.

Shared at a tasting by iowaherkeye. The body is garnet colored with a khaki colored head. The aroma was dominated by sweet cherries and some caramel. The taste was toffee and rich brandy. There was also a nice caramel finish. The body was smooth with a pleasing boozy finish. Well made.

#999

bomber shared by IowaHerkeye, thanks Joey.  poured a rich reddish brown with a small khaki head.  aroma was sweet malts and grain.  lively carbonation, but was silky smooth and easy to drink.  flavor was a delightful mix of sweet ripened fruit, malty notes of caramel & toffee with some alcohol.  a very nice doppel!

22oz via trade. (Thanks dickinsonbeer!) pours a deep brown with a small beige head. The nose is quite bock like ith fruity esters, nuts, plums. Taste is breadygrainy, earthy hops, fusel alcohol...its all cool while listening to BONDED BY BLOOD...hell yeah...body is medium and carbonation is just right. Good stuff for an American overhopped Doppelbock!!

A deep reddish brown bock, translucent and clear, with a thick light moka head. A rich caramel and pear aroma, wiht light nuttyness. In mouth, a sweet vinous beer with nice vanilla notes, nuts and a warming alcohol finish. Bought at Party Source, late 2006.

$5.50 bomber from JBC, Jessup, PA (rocking place). I love the malty silky texture and it has a somewhat bitter metallic glide which rolls over the tongue. Flavors of pumpkin-sweetened fruits, roasted apples, dark red grapes, and heat bursting from the seams of this melodic mix. The aroma has those malty alcoholic double bock qualities but does not spike enough to introduce the wonderful flavors that follows. If there was less copper there, itd make it to the top of my list.

Pretty shimmery clear amber color with nice sized head. Malty biscuty, roasted caramel aroma. The taste was the same with alittle smoke coming through. Sweet, smooth, and complex.  One of the better beers Ive had in awhile.

Name: Smuttonator
Date: 10/11/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Roadtrip

clear dark red, fine whispy beige head, touch of lace, sweet malty aroma with nice earthy touch, creamy body, rich malt flavor, good sweetness, nice earthy character almost like peat in a scotch ale, light bitterness in the finish

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+/4

Bomber 2006 bottle conditioned, finally pulled it out of the cellar. Clear, dark amber, average size head. Rich, sweet caramel and fruit aroma. Malty sweetness. Bittersweet, powerful flavor, malty and dry. Nice warming sensation slowly creeps up on you deep in the chest. Good.

8.5% ABVBeautiful red to dark amber color; thin head. Aroma of malt and caramel. Strong body, very strong caramel flavor, malty as well, with some sweetness; the caramel succeds in hiding the hopping, that seems to be quite good. Solid Doppelbock, good.

22 oz bomber. ALthough a little "hot" still this is some good stuff. Poured a very good looking clear red with a slight borwnish/purple tint and a big off white frothy head. Aroma had tons of sweetness, slight alcohol and some bready aromas. Flavor was smooth and sweet but needs some time to settle down. Very nice and Im sure this one will improve tremendously with age.

Hazy brown, with a small white head. Toasty nose, sweet, with caramel, pumpernickel, and some melanoid notes. Surprisingly fruity flavor. Medium sweet, with plums, a bit of chocolate, some dry bitterness. Very pleasurable, not really true to style--quite ale-like.

This was bottled on 2004. One inch, thick light-brown head.  Big aroma of heavy malt, dark bread, molasses, taosted.  Quite a bit of banana, as well.  Lots of dried fruit, too.  Soft carbonation and full bodied mouthfeel.  Taste has some dried fruit and caramel.

Poured a nice mahogany color with a slightly biege color head.  Aroma was richly malted with some caramel and dried fruit notes,; some alcohol was present.  flavor was mostly sweet, it had a nice mix of caramel and raisins. Alcohol was present.  Very full on the palate,  but a little gassy.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear mahogany body with a small beige head.  Aroma of raisins, sugary, herbs, and a hint of smoke.  Flavor of dark fruits, rich malts, and toastiness with a dry finish.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a chestnut color with a small tan head. The aroma was tangy, malty and slightly vegetal. The flavor was sweet, slightly roasty, had a light floral/fruity hop presence and had a malty and slightly vegetal finish. There was a hint of licorice and the hoppiness grew noticeably as it warmed.

Poured a very enticing translucent ruby red with a foamy, lacing off white head.  Raisins, spice and malt in the subtle nose.  Thick and syrupy on the palate.  Very fruity flavor, grapes, plums, raisins, caramel.  Finish is spicy and malty with a slightly medicinal twinge  I expected more from a doppelbock and even more from a Smutty doppelbock, but it was alright.

From a 22 oz. bomber bottle with bottling year, 2005, in the lower right hand corner of label, a blurb along the left side, sampled at cellar temperature in a flute glass.

Poured a clear auburn orange with frothy, foamy off-white/pale tan head, good retention, minimal amount of laced sticking.

Rich smelling nose, grainy caramel, plum and raisin fruitiness, and a light spiciness that meshes with faint whiffs of alcohol.

Good moderate carbonation and a crisp, dry, silky slick, smooth medium bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious tasting, caramel toffee maltiness, earthy dark bready, a plum and raisin fruitiness with a good sweet-sour flavor, spicy hops that have a nice soft bitterness towards the end, spicy and estery alcohol that provides a good warmth in the palate, and a dry fruity, malty finish with a light, lingering spiciness.

With being disappointed in the last couple of doppelbocks Ive tried, this was a welcome relief, tasty and balanced, an easy sipper, recommended.

22oz bottle, 2006 vintage. pours dense dark red with off white head that stayed. looks amazing. nose has toasted nuts, red fruits, and plums. flavor has toasted biscuit, red fruit, plums, raisins, brown sugar, caramel, and grapes. finishes sweet but not cloying with soft caramel and grape notes. alcohol well hidden. this is crisp, not sticky or syrupy like other doppelbocks. carbination is medium. very impressed.
22 oz. bomber. Poured a deep brown/ruby red color w/small off white head. Nose was  of caramel & toffee as was the flavor. The alcohol is well hidden.  Good brew.

Old bottle, maybe a year and a half or so.  Poured a clear dark mahogany with a fizzy off-white head.  Rich aroma of carmelized brown sugar, molasses, a vit of vanilla, and a touch of whiskey.  Flavor is sweet and dry at the same times with notes of burnt sugar, creme brulée, some molasses, and maple syrup, with also some aged whiskey thrown in to round out the finish and give this a bit of a refined dryness.  Long finish.  Alcohol is there but not to the extent where it betrays the beers actual ABV.  Really nice American Doppelbock that could hang with the best of the Germans.
Pours an amber color with a white head.  Aroma is sweet and roasted malts.  Flavor is malty, and roasty.

Sample at Firewaters in Atlantic City. This beer is a dark amber color with a thin light beige head that has decent retention. Patchy lacing. Nutty, malty aroma that has a good amount of hops around the edges. Rich, smooth body with roasted malt, bread and caramel flavors that are rounded out nicely by hops and spices. Alcohol is present but not overdone. The finish is full and sweet with toasted malt and caramel, leaving a nice hoppy aftertaste. Very good from start to finish.

Draft at firewaters...very little, to no head , just the suggestion of one..."mike & ike" scent and flavor...then changes to a hoppy mid-palate...finishes with a malty sweetness...sticky to the lips it is...sticky to the lips

Amber-brown color with a medium head.  Aroma is very sweet and malty with perhaps a bit of smokey-toastyness added in.  Taste is very pleasant, with sweet yet robust malty flavors and a bit of roast and smoke (Even smokier since Im enjoying it by a fire).  Really good D-Bock.
22 oz bottle thanks to dmac621. Pours a reddish brown with little head. Smells of malts and doughy bread. Tastes of malt, hops, and a slight alcohol finish. Very good bock.

Gifted from gwpoms wife, aka my sister. Poured a nice light ruby color, thick tan head, malty aroma, big malty flavor with alcohol present but not a detractand. Brussels lace adorned the glass till empty. One of my favorite styles and one of the best i have ever had. This is a must have beer.

Bottle.  Deep mahogany/burgundy color with a waxy off-white head.  Caramel malt and lager like aroma.  Slightly metallic and one dimensional.  It might be too cold, but Im not getting much, and Im suprised to see that its 9.6%, because i cant detect any of it.  Flavor is MUCH better.  Sweet caramel malts, smooth flavor, excellent finish.  This beer almost tastes like a baby barley wine.  Near perfect on the palate.  If this beer had a better aroma, it would be incredible.

Excellent brew with sweet burnt malts, but a decent earthy hops and alcohol balance. Syrupy body and full mouthfeel, its highly drinkable and reminiscent of a very clean traditional doppel. Fantastic for a non-German brewer.

(Bottle) Pours beautiful deep dark red with brown notes. Malty aroma with sweet almond, caramel, dark bread, dark syrup, brown sugar and some candy like tones. Fruity tones of both darker dried fruits like raisins and lighter fruits like pears. Sweet malty, sweet dark fruit flavour with an alcohol-ish sting. Undertones of dark bread, pears, raisins, milk chocolate, anise, caramel and a subtle smokiness. Round, smooth, creamy milk shake like mouthfeel. Light to medium bitter. Medium to full body.

Big thanks to porterhouse for trading this to me. Pours a dark clear copper with a good sized off white head. Nice candied malt and ripened fruit aroma. Flavor is malts, caramel, and a slight dry hop finish. Very good.

Ruby color, malty double bock aroma

smooth texture, candy like maltiness, notes of prunes  with subtle alcohol content, fiinshes with a hoppy bite.

Bomber. Clear copper with a large, fizzy head. Aroma of toffee and raisins with some alcohol. Taste is sweet and malty. Some amount of hop bitterness. Medium-strong bodied. Lively. Medium sweet finish.

Sampled at the O-Town throwdown. Poured deep copper color with tan head. The aroma was big and sweet caramel. Yum, makes it somewhat irresistible. Of course the flavor follows suit with tasty caramelness and also some light amounts of dark fruitiness. Very nice Doble Bock that doesnt become too sweet like others can.
Pours bright amber into a shaker.  Offwhite head recedes to skim surface. Deep malt aromas. Creamy caramel from front to back. Slight hop in the finish.  Alcohol well hidden.

Ruby-brownish-amber, nice kinda thin, creamy, persistent head and lace.  Nose packed with sweet, dark, bready, toffeish malts. A bit of fruit and vanilla as well. Medium bodied, creamy, sweet and luscious. Spicy hops come to balance a bit along wth a shot of  alcohol. Ends up with a smokey edge and grassy bitterness. This is really good. Could be a more subtle in terms of alcohol and hops but maybe a nap will meld this into a classic? I might even take this over a Celebrator, I know thats heresy but its not as it once was.

Dark ruby with a fairly large head, decent lacing and retention. Aroma is very raisiny with caramel and more darker fruits, some earth and alcohol. Flavor brings this with a medium syrupy body. Solid, I gave it a bonus point because of the bottle pic.
Pours a dark amber color.Caramel and chocolate on the nose with same on the palate only adding some molasses and nuts.A small hoppy finish.

2004 bottle.  Courtesy Matta.  Pours a rich reddish color with a very light white head.  Smells of monster caramel, sweet malts, and yeast.  The taste is somewhat similar.  I get alot of that big caramel and dark malts like a lot of doppelbocks.  I even get some butterscotch in the finish which I thought was a nice finishing touch.  Good brew.

From the 22 oz bomber, this poured an orange-tinged amber color with a sizable and solid foam head.  It throws a wildly bitter hoppy nose ... my nose says, "holy cow!"  This is an ubiquitousoen though ... the first swallow accosts my tongue with a solid malt tug, almost Scotch-like, yet with a hoppy bitter flourish at the finish.  The more I drink, the more I like.  This is a nicely assembled big (but not too big) beer.  (#2730, 3/1/2007)

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown beer with a thick tan head.  Very swet malty aroma.  Toffee and light caramel aroma.  A bit of toast and herbal bitterness on the finish.  Flavour is quite good, with lots of sweet toasted malt.  Light earthiness and a fairly hoppy finish.  Nice brew.

Bottle: Deep reddish brown in color with an off white head. Aroma, chocolate, toasted notes, bready malts, some caramel. Flavor, caramel, roasted malts, some earthy notes, fruits, and some vanilla. Pretty smooth, alcohol was well hidden.

22oz bomber from Florians.  Copper-red translucent body with a couple of inches of fluffy off-white head that leaves a fair bit of lacing and lasts quite a while.  Smell is a bit light, but consists mostly of nuts and caramel.  Tastes nutty, fruity, caramelly, with a trace of alcohol.  Flavor kind of dulls after several sips, but returns as it warms.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel.  Fairly drinkable.  Not bad.

Tap at Barcade: Pours an orangey brown, nice and heady. Deep sweet toffee malt aroma, doughy and some light cinnamon hints. Sticky body with loads of sweet bready maltyness. Some sour dough pretzel chewyness and a caramel sweetness. Theres a residual nutty dryness in the finish. A decent Doppelbock.

22 oz bottle-pours a big foamy light tan head and deep copper color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt-caramel, dark fruit.  Taste is alcohol, sweet medium malt-caramel, dark fruit , secondary hops.  Mild carbonation.  Occational.

from a 22 oz bottle.  Deep amber in color, with a small compact head.  Aroma is caramel, maple, raisins etc.  Taste also has those characteristics with a touch of toasted malt and lightly bitter finish.  alcohol well hidden, pretty tasty.

The color is nice, an orange red. Raisins, brown sugar, toffee, alcohol and a cough-syrup-like sweetness are among the many flavors oozing out of the palate.. The palate is oily and sticky but also bitter. This has a bit more hoppiness than I  like in a doppelbock.  Its not one of the best Ive had, and I had expected it would.

22 oz bomber .. clear deep copper color , thick off white head , decent lace . aroma of malty,bready caramel .flavors of toffee,maple and caramel. oiley mouthfeel and a little bitter at the finish . alcohol is noticable but not overpowering .
Clear copper-brown color, with a midsized white head. Bready malt aroma with hints of cocoa. Light malty sweetness, hints of roast and chocolate with a mild balancing bitterness.

Draft, at the Maproom, Chicago. Mahogany colour, with full beige head. Had a long day ahead of me and so this sweet, strong, sticky malty was a little like hard work. Complex but not what I need at the time.

2005 22 oz. bottle via trade with AxlLives - Pours a clear light brown color with a big off white head.  Thick lacing.  Has a sweet ester aroma.  Has a brown sugar malt and ester flavor.   Medium to full body.  Alcohol is slightly noticeable.  A very nice beer.  Thanks Bryan.

Bottle from Ross in my B-day package. Thanks mr. ranger. Pours a translucent mahogany with a fizzy off white head. Aroma of german malts and spicy hops, with some alcohol in the background. Flavor of maple, caramel, brown sugar, and alcohol. The bitter finish almost has an american barleywine bite to it, along  with the german like spiciness and maltiness. Very warming down the throat. This is a nice strong beer, without the sticky and full mouthfeel. Another goodie from Smuttynose.

2004 bomber.  Pours a brownish orange color with a nice sized foamy beige head.  Aroma is spiced malts with strong hints of figs,dates, dark brown sugar and warm alcohol.  Taste is autumn malty with a strong presence of spiced figs,dates,toffee and molasses.  Very enjoyable and the alcohol is well hidden.  Another tasty beer from Smuttynose.
sampled at barrel-aged brewfest. dark IPA appearance.  not much of a dopple.  bit watered down.  remotely lagerish taste.
dark copper finger head. smells malty. toffee raisin molasses. creamy viscous mouthfeel.. a little bracing in the finish  but over all this is a good beer.

Clear bodied oranged brown with a good streaming of bubbles lasting within for a good portion of its sitting. Two finger high roofing of smoothed creamy light tanned froth is nailed to the top. Keeps a solid thick skim of foam always present once settled and the lacing is mostly keeping close to the liquid in a thin sheet of fine foam. Some spots are flecked about across the glass.

Aroma is fairly milding with moderate malt tones of toffee, maple, molasses, and a slight toastyness that adds a nice bready-like drying note.

Thick on malt, moderate to mild and flavor, not sinking or heavy, very even set and smooth with a well-rounded taste and warming. The taste is hard to pin down as its nature is alluringly complex and simple in tone, yet has an urging length and tiny shavings of things in it that makes for good lip smacking intersest. Toffee and caramel are at the center in a milding set girth with a super creamy surrounding of all sorts of notings of dark fruits; raisin, fig, and a slimming dark cherry edge. Slightly spiced with a greasy backed, oily hopping adding a slight herbalness within the malty warmth. More so entering into the finish. The unique thing I find about both its flavor and thickness is a small breadyness that has a nicely set toasted realm to its overall scale of malt. Its slight, but somehow always present. A dull set fruityness in a bigger figgy, molassas tone really tends to take over as it goes as the warmth never leaves nor does the nicely added hoping in the finish. This definately gerw on me as I went along to the point where I was fixating myself on what exactly was going on. A perplexing palate soothing softy of a brew. When taken in to account of its Doppelbock style that it. 

Feel is quite nice. Soft, yeilding, smooth, creamy, uncloying sideness and thickness. Big mediumness to full bodied on the palate. Not too heavy and definately not any heavier then need be. As it goes down pretty damn easy. The wamth is all malts and flavor and not just a bunch of heat. It sinks in like a good breakfast and soaks in like a hot suana. Gradually making its case for you to enjoy and continuing to enjoy,without much hassle to your palate.

A pleasurable beer for sure. Its abundant in complexing flavor and warmth all the while keeping a simple ease about it. How the hell they do it? I dont know, but damn if aint a solid Doppelbock and then some. Onward Smuttonator!

Bottles courtesy of Pailhead and Bucknaked. Dark fiery mahogany with decent tan head. Huge caramel aroma, very toasty, with pine hop background. Almost BW-like aroma. Flavor much the same, except malt is all over. Caramel, toffee, roasted grains, maple syrup, etc... Some warming alcohol in the finish. Oily smooth mouthfeel. Overall very well done.

Clear dark brownish copper. Thin off-white head. Sugary lightly german hopped doppelbock aroma. Hops to me are Capital-esque. Flavor is nice and balanced. Has a roasted sweetness that kicks in after rolling around the tong a bit, and the sweetness is lightly hopped which is great.

Bomber.  Poured a clear ruby/orange with a short cap of creamy off-white head.  Nose was full of dark sugars and alcohol... pulled caramel, brown sugar, and molasses were there... woodsy/leafy hoppage, too.  Flavor was full with about a medium body... rich caramel, a hint of chocolate, dried floral hop bitterness, and heavy, fairly well-integrated alcohol.  Pretty smooth on the palate, but not-so-memorable... tacky bitterness and alcohol at the finish.  Quite well-done.

Pours a caramel brown with an orange-ish tone. I poured it slowly out of a bomber so I cant really comment on the head. Maybe I didnt let it sit long enough (a week) because its a tiny bit murky. 

Smells strong. Theres a gentle alcohol smell with a big malt behind it. Smells like a barley wine. 

Tastes like a barley wine too! Ah, but theres the smoky sour kick that makes this a pretty tasty Doppelbock. The flavor is really well done; tasty and wholesome. In fact, its giving me some pretty intense flashbacks from Germany. It must be good. 

The mouth feel is a little thin, but the carbonation works well with it. Little bubbles linger on the tongue and the roof of the mouth that compliment the slightly dry finish. 

Ill definitely have another one of these!

Pours a deep mahogany hue. Very nice looking beer. Not much head. Aroma is very rich with caramel, toffee, bread, and nutiness. Flavor is lots of caramel malts, some slight roastiness, with a touch of alcohol. Mouthfeel is very nice. Another solid brew from Smuttynose.

Thanks Illinismitty.  Pours with a deep amber-red body topped by a thick head with some lacing.  Its sweet and malty with nice caramel and toffee notes and an underlying hoppiness.  Medium to full bodied and smooth.
Pours out a darker brown color with very little head.  aroma is sweet and malty.  Flavor was very malty with a nice sweet finish.  The alcohol was well hidden.  this was a great brew.

2004 bottle from Bert (slob) Thanks!  Actually this was a bonus from him, and I was actively trading for this from Doclock, so I ended up with 2 bottles at roughly the same time.  Awesome!  Pours out a dark brown color, not much of a head so to speak. Smell is malty, rich, hoppy, slight alcohol, and interesting.  Taste is similar, very predictible with a slight sourness? to it.  Made it taste very nice, very smooth.  interesting, and very easy to drink for the almost 10% abv that this beer was.  Very good, one of the highlights of our night!

Had a few of these and surprised by its score. I really like this brewery. Had a nice caramel nose. Pure and simple.
Simply a deliscious brew to sip on while watching the tube or getting a box of beer ready for a trade. Rich malty flavor.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- my bottle courtesy of Thaichile. Pours an almost clear dark ruby-brown with a large lasting creamy off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, some chocolate, nuts and hints of dark fruit. Nice dark malty flavour with some alcohol but not too bad considering its 9.6%. Medium to full bodied. Good stuff, a nice version of the style.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of fruit, citrus, hops, and caramel. Flavor is caramel, citrus, and overly bitter.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, Pauls bottle.  Dark brown, lots of red, medium white head.  Mild malt aroma, some alcohol.  Wow, great taste.  Rich dark malt, intense nutty sweetness, a hint of burning alcohol (but not 9.6%).  Warming stuff, even in the middle of summer!  A solid Dopplebock.

Bottle (650ml).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, blankboys bottle .  Clear dark ruby-brown, small fizzy/creamy off-white head.  Roast malt aroma, light chocolate, hints of yeast and cream, very mild hops - quite grainy on warming.  Taste is a pleasant balance of sweetish roast malt and fresh sweet grain, I get a little cherry and plenty of booze - nice!  Average at best body, not much carbonation, nice and syrupy - quite boozy in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 After sampling quite a few different Smuttynose beers during a recent NJ/PA vacation Ive become a big fan of this superb brewery . However, this offering left me a bit dissapointed. Pours a translucent brownish-ruby color with a thin, but lasting beige head. Aroma was pleasant revealing caramel candies, figs, dates, toasted malt and spices, but seemed a bit too reserved and faint. Mouthfeel was somewhat thin and watery I thought for a DB, probably as a result of the high alcohol level. Flavors mostly in line with the aromas but a bit more assertive; sweet caramel, dark fruits, toffee, toasted malts and a mild spiciness.  Finish was sweet and warm, but quick. Wasnt too thrilled with this one overall.

Again,  not everything deserves to end in "ator" and not everything deserves to have a goat on the bottle.  This was a disappointment.  Pours dark reddish gold with a little head.  Taste of sweet malts and toffee, liglhtly hopped, but with nasty overtones of too much alcohol insufficiently masked and the bubble gum overtones of an unbalanced barleywine.

I was all in the mood to be smuttonated, but as I sat waiting the sensation that I had expected to be overwhelming simply crept up, tapped me on the lips and slowly slanked away. This may be an unfair assessment as it was actually far above fair, but dang blast it I blame Smuttynose themselves for making other beers I like a lot. I do hope they play with the recipe a bit as its not all too far away from being a beer I would like a lot and they could do it in two divergent possibilities - either make mmore malty or head own the hop highway.

22 oz bottle: Looks good.  A reddish-brown color with some nice lacing, good looking carbonation and a cappucino fulffy head.  Smell is nice too, roasted malts, some grassy hops, nutty.  Flavor doesnt live up to the appearence and aroma, if you ask me.  A little fruitier than I was expecting.  Some figs, raisins, an almost bourbon like flavor.  Also a grassier wheatish flavor than I was expecting.
Pour is dark ruddy amber with a thin off white head...smell is slightly roasty and nutty and very sweet...taste is slightly smokey and sweetly malty and rich...alcohol not noticable...

Bottle.  Aroma roasted caramel malts.  Poured a nice amber with a creamy tan head.  Flavor was good caramel,sweet malts and light hop to it.  Palate was good nice lasting tail to it just a tinge of alcohol.  Overall this was goodn.

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of fruit, citrus, hops, and sweet malts. Flavor is smooth for 9.6%, sweet, citrus, caramel, with a hoppy finish. Good body, good brew.

Too strong for a maibock, not enough color and body for a doppelbock. A miss on any bock style. Pour was copper colored, weak head and little to no lacing. Aroma was there for a doppel bock, lots of dark fruits (figs and raisins), but also some pilsner grassy hops. The flavor was light and grassy to go along with some fruity flavors and caramel malts, but the dark fruits werent there. An extra touch of hops in the finish to keep this thing honest, but too hoppy (maybe it was pepper as others have noted) relative to the rich hoppiness of other doppelbocks. Cant accuse this of being too malty and sweet, but it was perhaps too hoppy and bitter. No bread or dough. Maybe I shall dub this an imperial maibock anyway - not a good style. Mouthfeel was somewhat syrup-like and about right for the style.

2004 bottle date, Sampled June 2006
Pours with a rich, dark amber brown color which shows a brilliantly clear ruby hue when held up to the light.  The beer has a frothy full tan colored head that slowly dissipates back into the beer.  Ah the aroma is rich and malty; a mix of concentrated notes of prunes and raisins, but not sweet, chewy with a note similar to fresh malt extract and a sort of meaty quality.  After a bit of time it begins to pick up some sweetness, which accentuates the fruit character a bit.  The aroma is really nice, purely malt driven with perhaps a hint of oxidation, which only adds to the richness.

The taste is sweet up front, and in fact sweet throughout.  There is a light spiciness here in the middle; it is a bit like clove or allspice, but not really.  The beer is rich and a bit palate coating bit still not overly so.  This beer is quit drinkable, it just seems to disappear from my glass.  There are some notes of rum here, combined with the malt, which makes this a sweet, yet rich tipple.  Notes of chewy, freshly toasted malt.  Hints of cherry and perhaps a round note of raisins.

This beer is very drinkable, even enjoyable but it seems to be lacking a richness and complexity that I would expect in a great doppelbock.

05 bottle.  chestnut amber color, golden tan thin creamy head.  aroma is malty like good & plenty candy, and a little fig and banana peel.  flavor is a bit of ripe banana, bready malt like pumpernickel. and whiskey-like alcohol but not too hot.  some licorice and a little hop bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2007 Bomber thanks to Kramer17801.  Brown pour with a really nice head.  Aromas were malty, but with a bit of metal twang in there.   Flavors were better.  lots of dark malts.  bread, caramel, molasses, some spiciness.  hints of alcohol on the finish.  pretty good

(22oz bottle) Purchased at Downeast Bev in Portland, ME. Pours a large, frothy, almond-coloured head with a reddish-cola body. Nice oily legs. Nose is very mildly tinny and lemon-wheaty. Flavour (thankfully) is more potent - creamy caramel, roasty, leather and alcoholic. All in all a good beer though I expected more dimension than I experienced.
This was sort of bland. Aroma was very faint, smelled of wheat and hops. Flavor was mild, slightly sweet, and a little bitter,  ABV was noticeable.

Pours a deep amber-brown color with large tan head.  Very malty aroma of caramel, molasses, and honey with a banana-like overtone.  Bready flavor with heavy accents of honey and molasses.  A little bit of nutty bite compliments the slight taste of banana. Very traditional tasting dopplebock and very satisfying as well.

Bottled. Poured brown, with a medium brown head and nice lacing. The aroma is all malt and alcohol, with some fruit notes. The flavor is big and malty, with caramel notes to it, and a nice sweetness in the finish. Highly recommended.

bottle from Downeast Bev. Co. pours a brown copper color. with a lively head that dissapates quickly. aroma is pleasent but not strong enough for me. i had to practicly stick my nose in the beer to get anything. aroma/ taste are sweet and spicy, with some very nice caramel malts spicy in the finnish, slightly sour to. this gets better as it warms. not my style but a very nice beer none the less.

Bottle: Poured a clear nut-brown dopplebock with a huge foamy head with excellent retention. Huge aroma of freshly baked banana bread is quite just unbelievable. The freshly baked banana bread with a good slightly sweet malt backbone also dominates taste. Alcohol is well hidden and body is just above average with some medium carbonation. Definitely one of the best dopplebock I ever had.

Immediately after pouring, a powerful vanilla, malty smell was released, yet almost immediately afterwards, it faded into an alcoholic tinge with mild notes of smokey wood.  The color of the beer is beautiful.  Dark brown, looks like a dark cherry wood.  Head came thick and high, slightly more yellow than offwhite.  Taste is very complex.  Flavors of vanilla, maple syrup, caramel, and roasty, delicious malt.  Although most here seem to think alcohol is light, i find it to be a very noticeable flavor element.  Lacing is sort of ugly and all over the place, thick.  Finish is heavenly with a syrupy moutfeel and a long, dry caramel flavor coming through.  Overall I really enjoyed this 22oz bottle.  Ill definitely keep my eyes open from here on out.

22oz bottle via trade with goldtwins and someone else as well - Thanks Larry! - Pours ruby brown with a short offwhite head.  Aromas of sweet malts, caramel, vanilla, raisins, and even a bit of brown sugar.  Flavor is very much inline with the aroma.  Big caramel malts, a touch of vanilla, raisins, roasted nuts, some toffee all intertwined wonderfully.  Palate is medium bodied without much carbonation but a nice creamy mouthfeel.  Good stuff!

"Not sure what style this belongs in. Pour was a light copper color with almost 0 head and 0 lacing. Aroma was of raisins and other dark fruits. Flavor was off WAY off grass in there????? caramel malts and fruit. "
nice dark thick malty taste to it little taste of vanilla pretty nice beer not too amzing. goes down smoothly with a bite at the end.

Dark, ruby body with small off-white head. The aroma is loaded with caramel and toffee. The flavor is toffee, cherries, caramel, a touch of piney, nutty bitterness at the end. The mouthfeel is smooth with soft carbonation and a chewy texture.

Thanks for Blake for the sample.  Nice slight malty aroma.  Nice deep brown color, with little head.  Pretty good flavor, it was strong and malty.  Decent body and carbonation.  Overall, this was OK, but nothing special to me.

Lightish brown pour w/ a large frothy off white head w/ some soapy lacing.  aroma is sweet some light fruit, strawberries and maybe a fig, and a light alcohol and grain.  palate is lightly creamy and well coated.  flavor is sweet full carmel and a light fruity hop with some toasted grains.  Not much to it, not all that good.

2005 bottle.  The beer pours to a glowing deep orangish amber body.  Light beige head.  The aroma is light.  Syrup, light nuttiness, lightly alcoholic.  The flavor is strawberry seeds, roasty syrup, nuttiness.  The palate is very warming, medium bodied, smooth and creamy.  I dont understand how this rates so highly, however.
Good deep gold appearance with a light head.  Cleam aroma, fruits with maybe some strawberries.  Nice fruity start in taste, some cherry, clean ending.

Thanks to <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Shipments-Profile.asp for this trade last year. Finally opened to share at my clubs Bock tasting. So this is well over a year old. It hit us all with a big alcohol nose. Pours a nice head of foam even into plastic cups for sampling. Has some of the character of a Belgian dark beer, with some candi sugar sweetness. But very smooth, like "Cream of Malt." A great break from the Hubers and Leinies we had before cracking this one!

2005 Bomber.  I was starting to get a little down on Smutty.  Theyve been disappointing lately.  This one is different.  This is a damn good doppel.  Pours beautifully.  Great head atop a dark brown body.  It has a very ... um ... doppel type aroma to it ... roasted malts, buttery, nutty, a little syrupy (maple) and even a little bit of piney hops which adds a nice dimension.  Very roasty and buttery in the mouth, like any good doppel should be.  Despite the high ABV, you dont really taste it, its nicely masked.  Starts off bitter and roasty.  Roasted malts, earthy, nutty and piney hops.  It finishes pretty smooth, with maple syrup and butter.  Somewhere in the middle its pretty sweet.  Very good doppel, and its reaffirmed my faith in a good brewer.

Nice brown/amberish color,small but decent lived tan head.The aroma was malty sweet with a hint of caramel and maybe even a slight smoky side coming through as well.The flavor was very nice,malty and sweet with some mild fruit notes coming through a bit of smokiness and a light caramel hint towards the end.It also has a bit of a mildly heavy feel to it with the alcohol not being to noticeable in the beginning but definately makes itself known in the end with a nice warming effect going down.Over all id have to say this is a very nice brew and well worth having again and again.

We didnt love this one or hate it. The only distinguishable aroma was of a red wine, as well as alcohol. Pours a dark amber color with a large, fizzy off-white head. Hazy body. Both lightly sweet and acidic on the intial taste. Chalky residue on the finish. This beer seems like it wants to be sweet, but its not due to the overpowering alcohol taste. No malt aroma, but a malty taste.
This brew was recently tasted at a beer reception and poured out a nice amber with a thin long lasting head.The taste was of malts with just a touch of sweetness.Pretty good.

22oz. "Bottle Conditioned in 2005." Pours a beautiful mahogany with medium coarse bubbles forming a vigorous head that slowly retracts leaving a thin but impressively lacy layer of bubbles. The aroma is expansive and inspiring: radish, brandy, bananas foster, honeyed toast, and lightly roasted coffee comingle in the nose and permeate the flavor of the brew as well. The beer is just slightly sweet, though far less so than many others of this style with a healthy dose of hops providing harmony between malt, sugars, and alcohol. Doppelbocks can oftentimes be hit or miss for me and this one is right on the money. Quite impressive.

This is a great doppelbock esp. considering its huge abv.  Pours a nice deep amber, almost brown but clear and a nice thin lasting off white head.  Aroma is lots of munich malts, dark crystal, deep molasses and caramel with a touch of roastiness.  Lots of sweet powerful big malts throughout the flavor with munich and dark crystal dominating.  With all the sweetness and alcohol, this beer still isnt cloying at all.  The high abv isnt really noticed at first but you can feel it after about half the bottle.  Very nice.

Pours deep red with a two-finger, large-bubbled head. Big, sweet aroma of toffee, nuts, and smoke, with some very perceptible roastiness. A little whiff of alcohol, but less than Ive found in some less hefty Doppel Bocks. The flavor starts out just like the aroma, but heavier on the toffee, then turns fairly alcoholic before a dry and nutty ending with a hint of grassy hops. The alcohol lingers a bit, too. Overcarbonation gives the sweetness an unpleasant edge, but overall a good beer. Maybe too much alcohol; its more like an Eisbock, really.

22 oz. Bottle: labeled "Bottle Conditioned in 2004." Rich dark amber color with a decent tan head on pouring. Mellow aroma- mainly molasses with sweet yeasty notes, very little spice or citrus. Big malty first impression shifts to quite hoppy finish with a lingering bitter charcoal stout-like aftertaste. Surprised by the hops at the end. Definitely coats the palate. Id like it to finish more smoothly. My mouth feels like I just smoked a cigar.

10 oz glass on tap at Redbones, pre-EBF, in the company of MartinT, Rastacouere, tiggmtl and Olivier_MTL.  Id been looking forward to this for a year since the insane, instant sell-out around last years EBF....would it be worth the anticipation?  Its hazy copper-amber with a small bit of lasting, off-white head...lots of caramel and vanilla in the sweet, thick nose, also touches of blackberry and chalk....thickly malty, very sweet body, with light herbal (oregano, sage) hops, licorice....turns smoky, dry, and burnt-charcoal at the end....very rich, decadent caky mouthfeel, alcohol helps cut the thickness towards the finish.  Lovely, and worth the wait.

Pours a brownish almost golden orange amber with a large off white foamy head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts, with hints of fruit, licorice and some vanilla.  Smooth and almost creamy on the tongue. Not picking up much of the high ABV.  Flavor of a sweet yet roasted malt, brown sugar, lighter smoke and maybe some of the fruits I was picking up in the aroma.  Some slight alcohol tingle at the end.

From bottle.  Pours a deep orange/brown with frothy head that settles down with minimal lacing.  Nose has lots of sweet malts.  Flavor has more sweet malts with an alcohol finish.  Not the best in their BIg Beer series.

On tap at Milwaukees Landmark. Red brown color ,sweet malt aroma with hints of fruit and licorice, a pleasant malt, fruit and almost candy sugar taste,the kind of sweetness Iv always liked in a Doppel, yet I wouldnt call this a complex brew, a least not compared to Celebrator. Alcohol is well hidden.

Bright copper color with a hugh creamy looking beige head. Clean aroma. Scents of baked caramel and only a mild herbal backdrop. A touch of over-ripe fruit, which I believe is derived from the alcohol, but in no way a deterrent. I have this in three different glasses and it is amazing the different component each emits. This is pure bock "goodness". Truly a dopplebock. Chewy, lush and lightly oily in feel. Malt oozes from the glass and coats the teeth, gums and tongue. Toffee, caramel, dark brown sugar and an earthy pipe tobacco backdrop. Spicy finish with a touch of citrus. A solid doppel, where flavors dont quite mesh at times, but still one that would not hesitate to set down with. As I near the end of the bomber, this has more hops than needed and reminds be of another "imperial oktoberfest".  Prosit!
Poured a dark garnet color with a fine full tan head. Aroma was of malt and a caramel/vanilla scent. Flavor was a sweet roasted malt with a nice alcohol warming.

(22 oz. bottle (2005) from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/portland/ target=blank>Downeast Beverage Co.) Pours a fairly light rubyish brown. Creamy biege head stays around. Weepy lacing.  Aroma: malty sweetness, brown sugar, maybe licorice. Mouthfeel smooth but dryish. Tastes fairly sweet upfront, finishes with a bitterness that lingers. Some brown sugary taste. Sort of disappointed I couldnt pick out many distinct tastes, in other words this was good but not very complex or distinctly flavorful. A little biting, maybe some aging would mellow this a bit and bring out more flavors.

Over the past few years I have really come to enjoy a great Doppelbock.  This is a fine example.  Pours a dark brown/amber color with a thick tan head.  Has a sweet caramel aroma.   This beer immediately warms you as you drink it.  While cold it has sweet roasted malt flavor with a sweet lingering finish.  As it warms the alcohol becomes much more present.

SMuttonator pours to a beautiful, deep caramel color with a thick and creamy tan head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is sweet malty, with aromas of sweet malt, toffee, and hints of peppery alcohol. The palate is firm, with flavors of sweet malt, caramel, and toasty malt flavors, on a rich but very smooth and polished body. SMuttonator finishes with more sweet and caramel malt flavors up front, then ends with a malty, cloying, warming burn that lingers. 

An outstanding example of double bock, or dopple bock bier SMuttonator is an excellent tribute to the style.
I expexted a lot more. This double bock was loaded with hops. Very smooth in body and at 9.6%abv Itv was rather mild. Still was a very tasty beer.

This beer pours a reddish brown, looks more like a red ale as suppose to the darker brown in most doppelbocks Ive tried. I know this style can range in color but I just expect more brown than reddish. It leaves a small off white head that kind of lingers with the brew. The smell of this beer seems off to me, more of a grape sour smell comes out which throws me off a bit. As I continue to smell this beer more candied darker fruit begins to rise from the depths which now intrigues me. The taste is malty with a nice balance of hops to counteract that sweetness on the palate. Caramel starts off on your palate with medium carbonation followed quickly by a sharp herbal bitterness and finishes with some what mellow nutmeg spice characters. Overall this isnt the best beer from Smuttynose but decent.

Pours an amber/brown and clear with a thin but stubborn tannish head.  Smells of straw, yogurt, some vanilla and nice malty hints.  Taste is slightly bitter which is surprising for a dopplebock.  Once the initial bitterness subsides, nutty tastes start to come out along with some decent rosey and caramel notes.  Slightly fruity but not as over the top as some of the better dopplebocks.

2004 Bottling.

Aroma is rich sweet caramel that is full and fat in the nose. Cloudy amber in color with a thumb thick head. Very mellow after two years. Sweet caramel malts and plump ripe fruits like pear and apple with hints of spice and bread pudding. The alcohol is present, but not distracting. Smooth (fromt he rich malts) yet biting (from the alcohol) as you sip.
A decent doppelbock.  Smoky and delicious.  Strong alcohol.  This is one heck of a brew.

1.14.06  Doppelbock.  A big brutish beer.  A bestial bock.  Strong, dark, and to the point. No messing around here.  This brew gets in your face with  heavy dark malt and some serious alcohol.  This is for serious cowboys who arent afraid to play with lit fires.

Very smooth and thick, good for sipping on cold and snowy New England evenings.  A word to the wary, however:  this brew is not for the faint of heart, as the name clearly indicates.  

As always, the artwork on Smuttynoses labels for their big beer series is top notch (normally, I wouldnt even mention this, but its just that good).

seems a bit too bitter for the style, though the malt profile certainly dominates.  amber color with not much foam, the aroma is mild and malty.  deceptively sooth and drinkable thanks to the bock yeast, this bottle is well balanced.  while not on the level of celebrator, it is pretty decent.

overall not bad for the style, but just cant live up to my high celebartoresque expectations of what a doppel bock should taste like.  much more hoppy, but still has the malty overtones of a good doppelganger. good, but not impressive. i say this a lot.

Wow!  Pours chocolate brown with a quick to diminish head.  Aroma is carmel/toffee, with faint alcohol notes.   Flavor is of chocolate and toffee, with a great warming mouthfeel  Well put together beer!

Alcohol is present in this beer, not as overwhelming as in their Big A, but Smuttynose is NOT afraid to make alcohol part of the taste (take note, Stone and DFH!), and therefore you do not have an overwhelming hop or malt wave to wash away any intracasy in taste.  Excellent.
Dark, strong and malty. Seemed  little out of balance with noticeable alcohol burn. Otherwise, full, deep and satisfying.
Pours with a tiny white head that vanishes leaving behind a dark golden brown body. Sweetish aroma with the alcohol being prominant. Lively body with a malty taste.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 [22 oz. bottle] Pours a clear, reddish brown color. Aroma is kind of alcoholic and sweet, a bit like Maple syrup. Complex caramel malts initially make the flavors, with sweetness at first, then a nutty/toasty breadiness. Bitterness is lightly spicy, showing in the finish. Very pleasing, smooth mouthfeel. Alcohol warmth is not harsh in any way. An outstanding beer, I always look forward to this release.

A rich malty caramel aroma and flavor pervades this heady winter brew. Almost completely dominated by malt, the sweetness is kept in check with a slight rise in bitterness at the swallow and in the lingering aftertaste. A fine dopplebock with impressive attention to authenticity.
Light brown head on a brown body. Sweet malty flavor and a molassas flavor.

Bottle:  Courtesy of Secret Santa.  Lots of caramel, toffee, and chocolate int eh aroma with hints of nuttiness.  Pours a deep transparent reddish-orange with a moderate off-white head.  Flavors of caramel, chocolate, toffee, and molasses up front.  Light hints of roastiness in the background.  Light fruitiness and moderate citrus hops in the finish.  The hoppiness in the finish gives it a barley wine character to the beer that I really enjoy.

Slightly hazy brown coloured body with a nice tan head, completed by strong ruby highlights. Aroma of roasted malt, pit fruits, prunes and a light toffee scent. Medium to Full-bodied; Sweet nutty fruityness with a roasty malt flavour and a good balance between bitter and sweet. Aftertaste clean, but showing good qualities from the taste. Overall, a good beer - what the style should be, but missing some new complexities. Great to try though! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Village Pump Liquors in College Park, Maryland on 01-April-2005 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a dark ruby with a 1/2 inch fluffy head.  Lots of carbonation rising from the bottom of the glass, maintaining head well.  Aroma dominated by toffee and syrupy malt.  Some alcohol aroma as well.  Huge malty taste, tons of toffee, iced tea, and some alcohol.  Bitter lingering finish that seems a little harsh and muddled.  Very full bodied, sticky and syrupy with moderate amount of carbonation.  Overall, more of a one trick pony, huge malt but no balance.  Could be a little cleaner as well.

Bottle shared thanks to egajdzis (thanks!). Poured a medium and clear mahogany  color with an averaged sized head. Aromas of toffee, maple, light smoke, nuts, dark fruits and caramel. Tastes of dark fruits, medium alcohol presence, light smoke and light nuts. Medium sweet.
Bottle purchased at New Beer Distributors (NYC) - smooth and thick mouthfeel, the alcohol taste is hidden well, definitely a malty taste, a very good doppelbock
Bottle.  Candy like aroma.  Very matly taste and finish.  Leaves a taste of caramel in your mouth for a while after its gone.

As soon as I popped the cap, emitting the slightest of carbonation hisses, I knew this could be great.  Poured a nice rosy mahogany color with some tan bubbles along the edges and bubbly cloisters scattered intermittently on the surface.  Smells oh so good.  Rich, vibrant caramel, chocolatey and a little smoke on the backend paired with some toasty pecans.  Rich and sweet all over.  Flavor?  Yes.  This one gives an all-out one-two punch.  Velvety, solidified chocolatey caramel rolls in, resonating with an unparalleled richness, reminiscent of Rolos.  Some pecan casings and hazelnuts for robust dimension, and a soothing vanilla crème current underneath it all.  Woodsy-cedar backdrop to an ever present caramel decadence, transitioning to hints of amaretto in the aftertaste.So full-bodied its ridiculous.  Slowly seeps in and accentuates every nuance in its wake.  Balance has never been better.  Daunting, chewy and impressive malt complexity.  Carbonation is so toned down and at most preferable levels, and the noble hopping has never been more regal.  Finishes like white chocolate covered cashews.  Im so happy I drank this beer.  Big thanks to tpkenned for landing this one and sending it my way!

Hot hoppy brew. Well drank cold but the alcohol burst through more than I think it was meant too. Plenty of sweet bready malt join in with the aforementioned hot hoppiness and a bit of spice and raisin fruitiness too. Brwon sugar sweet on the tongue with a medium body and medium lingering finish. Decent.

Pours a very deep amber with a fizzy head. Intense malty sweetness in the nose with a candied cinnamon. Things are kinda messed up by the fizzy body. Flavor is very sweet and malty. Tons o munich. Med body. Heavily sweet finish. Doesnt really come together at all.

clear brown, small head.  aroma of liquorice, jelly candy, raisin, honey and bready malt.  silky sweet mouthfeel, light carbo.  sweet brown sugar and malt flavours with a little port like booziness.  nice

Clear ruby body with a tight, silky beige head. Aroma of toasty malt, fairly prominent earthy hops, and noticeable alcohol. Fairly sweet beer with brown sugar and maple characters and medium bitterness. Thick, fizzy mouthfeel. A very straight-forward, strong double bock.

Bottle.  Amber-caramel in colour with a thin tan coloured head.  Aroma was of caramel malt, cookies, dark fruits and brown sugar.  The flavour was of cookie malts, raisins, some spice and pepper, minor alcohol, slightly sweet.  Medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes with a medium bitterness, medium length.

Brown Coloring with Off White Ring/Skin.  Dry Malt Aroma.  Cloying..Rich Malt, and Prunes.  Bitter Aftertaste. Pretty Good Dopple!

Thank-you Larry Pitonka!

2004 Vintage:  I should rate it a perfect on the name alone... Dark brown color with a thin head.  Aroma of brown sugar and smoke.  Very malty body with a good caramel hit and some nearly crunchy sugarness.  Its definitely sweet and so something to sit back and relax with.  Very enjoyable!

dark amber, a little cloudy, creamy head, lots of caramel malts is the nose, taste has the same, some brown sugar tastes as well, gets a little bitter on the tail, followed by some strong spices, not a bad dopple, but a little plain.
Chestnut is appearance------ aroma. taste is same.  Alc not noticed.

Deep amber with impressive off-white lacework - rich, complex aroma of chocolate, cinnamon, caramel, brown sugar, some spices, alcohol in the background - the flavor has some of the largest caramel presence Ive tasted in a beer - cinnamon and sugar, some earthy, belgian-like qualities - a hint of nutmeg and chocolate near the back - very nice.

Pours brown like maple syrup with a thick brownish head.  Aroma has caramel malts, raisin, apple, brown sugar and toffee.  Taste has is alcoholic  for a Dopplebock yet quite effective.  It is certainly a good imitation of a Doppelbock.  It is Americanized because of the hops especially.

Pours hazy dark brown with medium, light tan head.  Aroma of bready malt, dark fruit, cognac, cabernet.  Tastes caramel malty, with big dark fruit presence and a dense, rich, complex finish that lacks balance to an extent.  Not in my elite echelon of doppelbocks, bit this one holds its own.

Bomber bottle from Mike: Ruby highlight deep amber hue with a nice frothy head and good lace. The aroma has notes of rich caramelized and burnt malts, apple, fig, brown sugar, earthy esters, and a hint of phenolic activity. The taste starts sweet, sugary, and a bit more fruity than I expected.  I get some spicy bitterness and sublime vinous notes as well. The feel is smooth and lush, not heavy but not thin either. The alcohol is noticeable and creates a warming upon drinking. Despite some flaws, this beers overall taste makes up for them. This is one dopple you know is a big one. Enjoy.

Draught at Blind Tiger Alehouse, New York. 
Dark amber. Sweet malt nose, with notes of raisins. Flavour is big, sweet malty. ABV is clearly evident.

04.30.05  Bomber from Big Beer series.  Dark amber, maple syrupy brown brew with only a trace of head that lasts.  Rich malt aromas, sweet, earthy, box oraisins.  My first impression is that the body is perfect, not too thick or cloying, light eff still present; but as the bottle is drained, I find the beer tends toward medium-thin, maybe to thin especially at the finish where Id like it to be a bit sticky.  Peppery spice middle to back and lingering.  Nasal alcohol hit after the swallow is a bit overbearing.  This would do well with a year in the cellar.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008  On tap at Coles 
 Appearance:  Slightly murky, brown brew with mid large creamy, tanned top. Good strong appearance. Nose:  Rich , sweet with brown malts . Hint of chocolate, caramel, little of plums and hops. 8- Flavor/Palate : Full bodied, rich , clean with warming effect. Balancing bitterness is found. Neat solid example for cold late nights. Traditional, clear cut sample with roughneck like soul.
Reddish brown colour, minimal head. I had no probs with the alcohol here, the taste was of sweet malts and fruits. Not bad at all.

2004 bottle, thanks to whomever trade this to me (sorry, forgot)  attractive ruby color with a giant beige head.  alcohol and sweetness in the aroma, slightly bubble-gummy.  excellent doppelbock, but still too alcoholic, as others mention.   i should have waited until next spring to drink this!
Ruby red with a thin white head. Lots of alcohol in the nose.  A little too hot.  Needs to be set aside for some time.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Orangey-amber with a little haze.  The aroma is assertively alcoholic and plasticy.  Strong big malts with light plastic taste.  Not bad but the balance is a bit to the strong side.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2006 The Lure:A veil of head circles the clear ruby. Roasting cherries and drying apricots. Possibly thick and sweet malt, with a vegetal pils malt undertone.

The Festivities:Roasted malt dominates the sweet and fruit components. Body is full, yet remains very drinkable. Hops of the herbal and earthy variety remain low-profile, but add an interesting flickering flame to the finish.

Transcendence:You know when you get to Grandmas youll get a hearty broth to calm that gurgling stomach.

Dark amber-brown w/ beige foam. Malty nose of caramel, molasses, plums, & prune. Full-bodied, chewy feel w/ low carbonation.  Rich malty flavour of caramel, plums, prunes & nuts. Smooth alcohol presence.

Aroma of sweet malt for days, alcohol is duly noted too. Cloudy brown, a tiny tan head. Full flavoured malt, some molasses, treacle and plums. Medium bodied, strong alcohol finish, warming. A fine example! Thanks Shadey

Brown sugar, dark fruits, nuts and a light vegetal note to the boozey aroma.  Dark mahogany brown with light tan/off-white head that recedes to lasting cover.  Strong, sweet and malty with nutty marzipan tones and a nice interplay of dark fruits and alcohol.  Light cabbagey notes appear and recede throughout the tasting.  Somewhat low carbonation.  Medium body with plenty of residual sugars.  Bottle enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere.

malty and carmel, good dark colour, roast. Some fruitiness. Chewy nutty. Some more please. Hops noticeable in finish, nicely carbonated. Dry aftertaste, alcohol whollop.Thanks Shadey for bringing to Radekfest 05, sample 23.

Dark copper hue wears an off-white 1cm lasting head. Aroma is fruity and sweet (brown sugar) creamy and quite vegetal (bean). Earthy and candyish malt. Understated leafy and almond skin like hops dont quite fight off the startling vegetal character that restrains the global charm. Surprising level of alcohol comes out a bit fuelic.. but 9.6%.. woah Ok then. I would just have expected a body a bit fuller then, it is not even medium bodied, though a bit oily as of now. Straightforward well made malty doppelbock.

This is a beautifully colored brown ale with some hints of red at the bottom. It doesnt hold much of a head but it still looks good in the glass. It has a sweet aroma of fresh cut cantoloupe with some floral undertones. A good beer and one worth finding and trying.

Bottle pours dark amber, or rather reddish caramel, large frothy sand colored head, with nice brewers lace.   Malty nose, very sweet, bready, but only slightly biscuity (whew).   As it warms, alcohol on the nose becomes more apparent. &nbsp Quite sweet and malty on the tongue, yet not overly done (at least its to my liking).   Good body, with a smooth moufheel.   Finishes sweet, bready, and very malty.   Nothing fancy, but seems extremely solid.   Its also quite filling. &nbsp The 9.6% ABV, while not extremely well hidden, is quite palatable.  Thanks goes out to ClarkVV for the trade!

Pours a two-finger white head that leaves a little lace. Clear amber color, nose is raisiny so is taste. Starts and finishes malty and sweet but not cloying, full bodied - very easy to drink alcohol is not noticeable.  22oz bottle, $3.79 from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [22 oz. bomber] Pours a dark copper color with a slightly thin white head. Very cloudy. Very malty aroma with touches of metal. Mostly sweet malts though. Lots of flavor throughout this beer. Sweet malts, caramel, fruit, smoke and alcohol. Well blended and the taste got much stronger as the beer warmed up. Near the end, there was a lot of flavor. I was a big fan of the label. All Smuttynose labels actually... we had recently killed a case of Robust Porter and were commenting on the label. When I was asked what was on the label of this one, the only thing I could reply with was a fuzzy goat.
Delicious Doppelbock. The nose and palate are slightly metallic, but only slightly. Has a fantastic maltiness. Vaguely chocolatey and coffee-nosed.

Ok last of the beers sent by JahNoth .
22 oz bomber.
A nice attractive Doppelbock,dark ,mahogany brown with a huge dark cream coloured head.
smell is as expected quite malty, with a tinge of alcohol.
The malts dominate this one, chocolaty,creamy malts, some fruitiness ( blackberries etc), a woody aspect which is pleasant and a hint of smoke..alchol is detected but it compliments this one.
Great feel on the tongue,quite smooth and pleasant.
Good drinkability though maybe one bomber is enough per night
2004 Bottle conditioned
Poured a clear dark amber color.  Aroma of molasses, sugar, and raisins.  Malty flavors sweet with dark fruit.  Light hops.  Light to medium body.  alcohol on the finish and warming.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2014 Aroma is off--fruity vinous and seems to have lots of yeasty bananas.  Small roastiness present, but this really smells more like a belgian ale.  Transparent ruby-brown cola color with a fine light tan head.  Sweet and very sticky.  This is quite vinous and banana-like as well.  Just tastes off for the style and is way too sticky for me.  Not a fan of this one. (5/4/5/2/11)~~~~~~RE=RATE~~~~~~~Surprised to find a bottle of this at the local BevMo in Natomas.  Didnt know Smuttynose distributed out here.  The aroma is really sweet with lots of toffee notes and some fruity character.  Transparent copper color with a medium, off-white head present.  Fair lacing.  A little lighter in color.  Starts with sweet toffee maltiness, before this becomes rather ethanolic and quite boozy.  Light-bodied, and a little water.  Ethanol taste and burn lingers.

Caramel/apple/alcohol.  Very deep, mellow sweetness--raisiny-honey-figgy notes.  Kind of a barleywine-esque feel without the hoppiness.  Not bad, although I still prefer their maibock.  Smuttynose scores again on a malt-based platform.
This one has a copper body with a really good head. Theres a rich malt and alcohol that make up the aroma and flavor. Fairly sweet.

Clear still copper appearance with a frothy light tan head.  Aroma is rich, malty and full of caramel with good authentic German lager yeastiness.  Starts full, malty and sweet.  Well-balanced, clean and candy-like finish hides the alcohol well.  A nice doppelbock. Thanks to Probiere for sharing this at the Southeastern Gathering!

Reddish body, lots of rising carbonation, medium-sized, dense tan head, slightly sweet malty nose. Rather thin malt in the body, with a good hoppy bitterness. Alcohol warms as it goes down. Not a great example of the style, but I very much like this one anyway.

Hmmm...a "leafy" doppelbock.  Warm butterscotch aroma, and a caramel taste.  Hops come back for the finish.  This is more in the Strong Ale category, with less malt than advertised.  All that said- pretty tasty.

Thanks to Probiere for bring this to the SE gathering at KPs.
Clear deep mahogany color with an off-white head.
Big malt aroma that leads in to a caramel flavor that comes across the tongue smooth and easy. More Bock than a Doppelbock to me. A bit of chalkiness inthe finish, but overall, not too bad.

Caramel apples and alcohol are dominant.  Deep red-brownlooks more like a barleywine.  Heavily sweet flavor shifts to a heavily sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic finish.  Medium full body, creamy texture, light carbonation.  The bottom line is: not terribly complex, but tasty and drinkable.  Thanks Em.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2007 transparent mahogany color with thick French vanilla head.  resinous and bitter, I was drinking it too cold in all probability.  vanilla and nut but the maltiness was not centerstage, it did improve on warming.  I liked their MaiBock big beer from last year a lot more.  The ethanol sure does kick ones butt though.

Quite large, light orange head.  Settles slowly and reduces to a thin dense foam.  Light carbonation.  Nice roasty aroma with hints of vanilla, nuts, roasted grains and a bit of milk.  Color is a dark mahagony red.  Big alcohol presence.  Tastes like more that 9.6%.  Little fruity.  Some of the roastyness is overpowered by the alcohol.  Body a little thinner than I expected.  Warms as it goes down.  Some malts but not enouhg to give it a good dopplebock body.  Finish is resinous and has a strange bitterness.  Not as good as I had hoped for but an ok brew.
Draft: Dark reddish/brown. Nuts, burnt malts in aroma, Malty sweet flavor, yet body was entirely too watery in my 16 ounce sample. Light bitter finish. Decent

UPDATED: APR 27, 2005 Bottled. Dark ruby. Raisiny crystal malt aroma. Sweet an malty, but with clean, hard, syrupy mouthfeel. Theres caramel and some apples. Grassy bitter finish. Lacking in malt character.

Clear reddish brown colour, small tan head. Deep malty aroma of nuts, cherries, cookies and burnt sugar. Hearty and very malty flavour of nuts, toasted bread, burnt sugar and alcohol. Full bodied. Long, hearty warming aftertaste.
Pours a gorgeous red with a thick white head.  Super malty flavor with a hint of apple.  Thick, sweet, and wonderful to drink.

A gorgeous red mahogany body with a huge beige head.  Aroma is sweet malts and dark cherries with a little alcohol.  Smooth, sweet malt flavor with hints of raisins, figs, and cherries.  Nice alcohol warming with more cherry flavors in the finish.  This is a great doppel!!

Provided by John (JCW) at a tasting.  Clearish red-brown body, thin off-white head.  Nice caramely, bready aroma.  Dense caramel body with dark fruits (including a touch of raisin and prune).  Very toasty with plenty of brown sugar in the finish.  Medium-bodied.  Alcohol was detectable (didnt realize the ABV was so high in this beer!) in addition to a touch of smoke.  A solid, competent American doppelbock.

Bottle. Chestnut color, fuller tan head. Nose is of sweet malt, some lighter caramel and brown sugar. Full flavor-quite sweet but not over the top. Brown sugar again, loads of sweet malt, touches of some dark fruit. Medium to full bodied and a general good job of masking the alcohol. Very good.

On tap at the Pizza Plant after a godawful meeting.  Oakey brown color, off white head.  Nose is sweet malt.  Flavor is of super rich malt, brown sugar, plum, cotton candy.  Not cloying.  Long finish.  Yum!  Glad I have a bottle of this stashed away

Clear copper, frothy off white head.  Complex nose of caramel, toffee, butterscotch, cherry, plum, and molasses, with a slightly vinous undertone to it.  Well balanced, very malty, with a nice hop bitterness to round it out.  ABV shines through just a touch as well.  Full bodied, pillow soft carbonation, warming malty, dark fruit like finish.  Another winner from these guys....
This is a good Double Bock.  Sweet, malty, and dark fruit flavors.  Finishes smooth, rich, and creamy.

Bottle, from Julios. Good nose, Rum, vanilla, carmel, little dried fruit, apple and raisin. ABV. Clean orangy brown color. Good head that faded. Sweet flavors. Chocolate, carmel, raisin. ABV bites. Medium body, Creamy/oily mouthfeel, Sweet dr finish, again ABV has bite. Real nice brew. Smuttynose continues to be one of New Englands best.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle:  Clear copper with a large small-bubbled off-white head.  Rich aroma with dark fruits, and fresh bread. Thick chewy body with lively carbonation, starts lightly sweet, ends sweet.  Another great beer from Smuttynose.

Bottle. Chestnut color with a small tan head. Malty aroma with hints of butterscotch. Mildly sweet malt flavor with some dark fruits and butterscotch
again. If it wasnt for the slight butterscotch aroma and flavor, I would have given this beer a much higher rating.

Bomber... Clear, copper lager with a mid-sized, frothy, off-white head. Good retention. Butterscotch, port and black cherry nose. Bitter-sweet flavor. Huge malt. Moderate hops. Alcohol. Full-bodied and sticky with lively carbonation. Lengthy, bitter-sweet, grassy finish.

Sampled at the Extreme Beer Fest. Pours a coppery color with no head. Aroma of dark fruits, malt and alcohol. Flavor of dark fruits, malt and alcohol with a bitter finish. Light to medium body, syrupy texture. Good but nothing impressive.

Thanks to Jooeec5 and Jim. This special bottle poured dark mahogany, like fine wood cabinets. Big fruity aroma and had nice tan head. There was a taste of caramale and malts, full mouth feel. Good carbination as well. I enjoyed this and would grab it again if I see it.

Beautiful clear mahogany with a thick off-white head. Aroma of bread, caramel, floral hops and a zing of alcohol. Very sweet and malty. Taste has notes of roasted malt, dark fruit/dates, smoke/peat, caramel, brown sugar, nuts, breadiness, chocolate, a hint of whiskey and a solid dose of hops. Some alcohol in the finish along with some roastiness and moderate bitterness. Full, round and creamy on the palate with subtle carbonation. Nice puffy lacework with great head retention. Overall, a very nice beer.

Man, this just, once again,  proves how awesome Smuttynose is.  Viva New Hampshire!!!  Dark brown/blood red color with a fruity aroma.  Big malty taste that is smooth smooth smooth.  Love name of it too (a sheep on the bottle, hence the name).  Im going to buy a frickin case of this.

Small tan head thats short lived with slight lace. Clear, dark amber/red hued brew. Medium sweet malt nose with hints of caramel and a weeeee bit of alcohol, errrrrrr. Med/full body, silky smooth mouthfeel. Alcohol up front, cherries, bready malts and a faint roastiness top it off. Finish is medium dry with some warming alc. heat FO SHO!  Needs to lay down fer awhile?? Still an interesting ride though. Again, Again!!

On draught January 2005 at Redbones.  Delightful color to this, reds, golds, oranges and coppers all mix to form a brilliant, deep, colorful body.  Small light beige head.  Aroma of German yeast, smooth hops and sweet caramel and toffee.  Very sweet up front, with apparent hops quickly coming to balance.  Remains mostly sweet however, with a tingly, strong carbonation to it and a medium-full body.  Brandy soaked fruit, bittersweet yeast and orange citrus flavors all come in to play.
